editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A Pleaſant and VVitty COMEDY: Called, A New Tricke to Cheat the Divell.
LONDON: Printed by Iohn Okes, for Humphrey Blunden, and are to be ſold at his Shop in Corne-hill, next to the Caſtle Taverne. 1639.

div.head: To the Courteous Reader, and gentle peruſer.
div.p: TO make too long an explanation of the worth of the Author, or to commend the Worke with Eloquent words, were but to delay the time, and dull thy expectation: It is a Comedy which hath bin often acted, and ſo well approved; that I hope none will diſlike of it now in the reading: But the Poem it ſelfe, being now an Orphant, and wanting the Father which firſt begot it, craves a Patronage from thy gentle acceptance: my hopes are, it will prove no leſse pleaſing to the Reader, than it hath formerly beene to the Spectators; and ſo I leave it to thy charitable Cenſure.

div.head: A New Tricke to Cheat the Divell.
Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Slightall, and Miſtreſſe Anne.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: May I periſh then, if ever thought was
Harbour'd in this breſt,
That did intend you harme;
Your Father hath conſented you ſhall be mine;
Your Mother ſtill holds off: but having yours,
I care not who withſtands;
I am fixt your Servant and true Lover.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: And I thine, in ſpight of Father, Mother, kinſfolkes,
Friends; thy Anne will ne're forſake thee.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Then here my deareſt, doe I plight a vow,
And ſweare by thy owne vertuous grace and ſweetneſſe,
By thoſe intrammell'd Raies, thoſe ſtar-like eyes
Endymion bluſhes on; thoſe Ruby lippes,
Where a red Sea of kiſſes is divided
By rocks of pearle, by theſe joyn'd hands, and all things
That have tyed my love to thine; Ile ne're forſake thee.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Slightall, My vow is fix'd, no more, my Father. Enter Changeable.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: I have over-heard all,
My bleſſing on you both:
Slightall, I love thee, and am glad th'haſt ſped;
How I have pleaded for thee, Minion, you know.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Father I doe, pray you for a while
Conceale it from my Mother.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: Feare not that wench, how I have labour'd with her
You know well, but no conſent from her, it is impoſſible:
What I have ſtor'd for thee high Heaven does know,
But 'tis my love, which ſtil continues to this wayward Girle
Who never could have pleaſ'd her Father better
Then in this mutuall and conjoyn'd aſſent. Ent. Mrs. Changable, & Mr. Treatwell.
Further I would proceed, but ſee, my wife
Conſorted with a ſtranger.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Sir, here's a gentleman (Slightall ſo neere?)
Deſires your conference (no deviſe at all
To ſhift him hence?) His buſineſſe craves diſpatch,
And is of ſerious urgence; 'twould become
Your modeſty to ſpare us ſome few minutes,
Since it no whit concernes you.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: He ſhall ſtay, hee's now ingraft aſcien in our Family:
Therefore what us concernes muſt needs touch him,
Sonne, ſonne, be conſtant to your place I charge you.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: Remove for no man, now ſir ſpeake your mind.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: What in a place ſo publique?

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.l: A place more private would become my meſſage,
And give it gentle hearing.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: Pray with draw, it comes from a great man.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: Came it from on of the Guard, from Sir Iohn Falſtaffe?
Nay, Hercules himſelfe; with bumbaſt limbes
It ſhould have publique audience.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: Now your bigge man, name him I pray.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: I cry you mercy, my honourable friend, I pray
What ſervice will't pleaſe him to command us?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: Liſten unto't, 'tis all for your preferment.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: Feare and doubt perplex me equally.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.l: The Lord my Maſter, to whom the fame of
Your faire Daughters beauty hath throng'd by infinite
Tongues, hath in his breaſt
Tooke ſuch a ſtrong impreſſion, that hee's pleaſ'd
(So your conſent and his may paralell)
To make her his faire Bride.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: You ſhall be a great Lady.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: And take place of al Knights wives in the Shiere.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.l: Sir, I have full Commiſſion from his mouth
To treat ſo much; and what I undertake
He hath engag'd his honour to make good.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: His honour? ſo you ſhall be honourable,
Be every day Caroach'd; and ride in ſtate.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: I wiſh his Lord ſhip had not ſent ſo late,
My word is paſs'd unto this gentleman;
Which to my power I will not change, nor breake
For any King or Keiſar.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: But you ſhall ſir, and ſend his Lordſhip ſatiſfaction
Even to his beſt deſire; tell him from me
She ſhall attend his pleaſure: you ſhall, Nan,
Vſe him with all obſequious reverence,
And gladly embrace his motion; Girle, you ſhall.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Forward ſir, if you withſtand the fortune of your Daughter
In this tract of preferment without yours.
Send him faire humble language, doe my wench
Accept his noble pleaſure, and returne him
Courteous and loving thankes; thinke what it is
To be attended, honoured, and advanc'd.
My Lady Anne you ſhall.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: How poore and ſlightly Miſtreſſe Slightall ſounds?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Good troth and ſo it doth.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.l: But Donna Anne, Madona, Madam, Lady,
What breadth thoſe Titles beare?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Miſtris? thou ſhalt have ſuch to be thy ſervants,
And curchy to thee when thou turn'ſt thy head;
Bow at each nod, and make their Farthingales,
At every word thou ſpeak'ſt, to kiſſe their heeles.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: What ſhould I ſay? or how in equall
Ballance beare my ſelfe?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Footmen, Pages, and your gentlemen Uſhers,
Walke bare before you.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: For all the ſtiles of honour in the World,
I would not breake my faith.

sp.speaker: Wi,
sp.l: Where I was wont to call thee baggage, Nan,
And paltry Girle, I muſt not dare to ſpeake to your
Honour, without a Prologue of ſome halfe an houre long,
Which muſt begin, an't pleaſe your Ladiſhip.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: 'Tis paſſing good an't pleaſe my Ladiſhip.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: Son Slightall, for that Title Ile ſtill faſten
Upon thy name, adviſe me' what ſhall we doe?

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.l: Me thinkes the motion might be faire and even,
To make her miſtreſſe of her owne free thoughts
And chuſe where ſhe beſt likes.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: Weele ſtand to that, let it be put to her.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: In her knowne love I am ſo confident,
And of her faith ſo conſtantly aſſur'd,
So void of all diſtruſt; that I give backe
All intereſt, Title, claime, and Ceremony
T'attend a ſecond Cenſure. Mriſtris Changeable,
You now are your owne woman.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: Madam, may it pleaſe you take a ſecond choiſe?

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: Here's Gentry, and here's Honour, Mrs. or Madam.
A ſingle ambling Nag, or a Caroach
With foure, foure great Dutch Mares; a private Gentlewoman
Or a great Lady, my worſhip, or my honour;
To be a Wife to a Squire of low Degree,
Or a Lord Baron: Gentry ſhall give place,
And in a puff'd ſtile his Lordſhip Ile embrace.
Thus, Slightall, I thy Title will out-ſtrip,
That all may ſay, there goes my Ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: You have your anſwer Slightall, and good ſir,
Returne this to my Lord.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: Sir be my witneſſe, I have no hand in this.

div.stage: Exeunt all but Slightall.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: All come to this? ſhone the Sun bright i'th' morne
To be ere Noone envelopp'd in this Cloud?
To be forſooke, deſpiſed, and diſgrac'd
All for a verball Title? ſhall I avenge me
On the proud Don, or this his changeable ſtuffe?
Whoſe name and diſpoſition ſuite ſo well:
Something I muſt, but in the interim
Never to fixe a conſtant thought againe
Upon that Moone-like ſexe: Ile weigh them all,
Poore, rich, old, yong, and middle Age alike;
Make no diſtinction 'twixt the looſe and chaſt,
The Matron and the wanton, women kind;
For the ſo baſe inconſtancy of one,
Henceforth Ile forme my ſelfe alike to all:
Licentiouſneſſe ſhall be my Miſtreſſe now,
Voluptuous pleaſure, riot and exceſſe
My future ſtudy; Ile let looſe deſire
And appetite unbridled; and the more
Of that intemperate Sexe I can corrupt
Count it my greateſt deede of Charity:
And for thy ſake, thou falſeſt faire; I vow
Affection and all loyall Love t'abjure,
Striving to make the cleareſt ſtreames impure.

div.head: Act. 1. Scaen. 2.
div.stage: Enter Ʋſurer, and his Scrivener.

sp.speaker: Scri.
sp.l: Faith never worſe, Merchants are wary,
Tradſmen provident, Artificers turn'd frugall, and I thinke
All the World will prove good husbands.

sp.speaker: Ʋſu.
sp.l: Better they, with halfe a number of that thrifty world
Were three parts hang'd; but ſo much for the City:
What newes in Holborne, Fleet-ſtreet, and the Strand?
In th'Ordinaries among Gallants, no young Heires
There to be ſnapp'd?

sp.speaker: Scri.
sp.l: Th'have bin ſo bit already
With taking up Commodities of browne paper,
Buttons paſt faſhion, ſilkes, and Sattins,
Babies, and Childrens Fiddles, with like traſh
Tooke up at a deare rate, and ſold for trifles
That now ſcarce one will bite.

sp.speaker: Ʋſu.
sp.p: What a world's this? what will't grow to in th'end?

sp.speaker: Scri.
sp.l: Faith ſir Heaven knowes,
We Scriveners fare the worſe by't.

sp.speaker: Ʋſu.
sp.l: How ſmart wee then?
We Mony Maſters, from whoſe bagges you feede,
And without whom your Pens would caſt no Inke?
Nor your VVaxe take impreſſion: none in chace?

sp.speaker: Scri.
sp.l: Yes, ſir, I have one Spung that could you ſqueeze him,
Would yeeld good ſubſtance.

sp.speaker: Scri.
sp.l: Yes ſir, he hath in Acres glebe and medow,
Upland, and Dale, in woods and arrable;
And though in name a private Gentleman,
Yet hath he three faire Lordſhips, beſides Sheepe-walkes,
Parkes, and other large Demeſnes.

sp.speaker: Scri.
sp.l: I have dealt cloſely with a man of his
To undermine him, one that ſoothes him up
In all his riots, quarrells with his thrifty,
Leades him to Game and guzzle in Vaulting houſes,
And places of bad fame.

sp.speaker: Ʋſu.
sp.l: An honeſt fellow, Ile warrant him;
Can hee doe ought in this?

sp.speaker: Scri.
sp.l: Hee's one to whom he truſts his whole Eſtate,
And can doe all things with him: In theſe Lands
I promiſ'd him, if when they were in ſayle
That I might bring his Chapman; a round ſumme,
To which he ſeem'd to liſten.

sp.speaker: Ʋſu.
sp.l: 'Twas well ſcented,
Nor ſhalt thou loſe by't: there's a ſhare for thee;
Acquaint me with the further Circumſtance,
In which I would be perfect. Enter Roger and Geffrey, 2. Servingmen.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: I doe not like this ſhufling.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.p: What Roger, al amort, me thinkes th'art off o'th'hookes?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Yes faith, and Henges too, I'me almoſt deſperate,
And care not how I am.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.l: Faith I was never on a merrier pinn,
Nor my breaſt lighter hearted.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: So, and if thou beeſt not pleaſ'd with that,
Thou muſt prepare for worſe.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Faith ſcarce with thee, thou art not worth my anger

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.p: Are we not of one Houſe?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Yes, but I hope we ne're ſhall be of one heart,
My fellow no better than a Pander?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Yes, would that were all, a Traytor to that Houſe
Where thou hadſt thy firſt Bread, and almoſt thy being;
Thy making I am ſure, but ne're that poyſon
That ſwells ſo in thy boſome: My good old Maſter,
Heaven reſt his ſoule, upriſing, and downe lying,
Kept twenty ſtout tall fellowes, whom thy baſeneſſe
Hath ſhrunke to two already; if this Ryot
To which thou ſtill perſwad'ſt the young man hold,
We ſhall be none, he nothing.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.l: I could anſwer thee, but that I ſpy two Gentlemen,
With whom I have buſineſſe of my Maſters.

sp.speaker: Ʋſu.
sp.p: And to me none more welcome.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.l: All's plotted, we want money, ſell we muſt,
The rate we live at muſt have freſh ſupply;
Ile give you the whole project.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Get you together, for a true-love knot
Tyed by the Divell, may his Dam unlooſe it,
For I ſhall never: a Scrivener, an Ʋſurer, and a Pimpe,
All joyn'd in one, to ruine a yong hopefull Gentleman.
Now are they turning an old three mens Song,
We be knaves all three, mount your notes aloft;
For he that I nam'd laſt will beare the burthen;
A load beſt fitting him, you'le find him one day
A fellow of excellent carriage, hee'le beare with you,
Becauſe he loves you ſo: So now all's plotted Exeunt all three.
And there's a Lordſhip, or a Mannour at leaſt
Gone at one lift: but what to doe with money,
Of which the leaſt is like to come to him
That hath moſt intereſt in't; ſome to the Pot,
Part to the Pipe, not leaſt ſhare to the ſmocke:
And what remaines to gaudifie the backe,
Muſt fill the Cheaters pocket; oh my old Maſter,
Should thy ſoule ſee this, it would ſuffer for't,

As my heart bleedes to thinke of't.
Enter Slightall, & 2. Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Gen. 1.
sp.p: But did ſhe breake ſo with you?

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Worſe than a ſhop-keeper, that hath
Run long behind hand.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: S' foot, like a puffe, a Feather▪ 'tis my Lord
Muſt deale in whole-ſale with her Lady ware,
And I am quite caſheir'd.

sp.speaker: Gen. 1.
sp.l: Troth I commend you, that, ſo loving her,
You doe not tak't to heart.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: A heart? at heele; that poore worme, Love,
Which ſome doe ſtile a God;
I thus tread underfoot, ſtampe on his ſhaft,
And trample on his Quiver: I muſt confeſſe
I once lov'd beyond thought, but when I ſaw
My troth ſo bafled, and my faith deſpiſ'd;
I ſet it at defiance, and I now
Will be for all, or any.

sp.speaker: Gen. 1.
sp.l: What, ſo generall, I pray? is't poſſible
One that hath lov'd ſincerely, as you ſay
You once did, ſhould with ſuch an eaſineſſe
Change his affection?

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: I love all faſhions, features, formes and faces,
Proportions, ſexes, ages, and degrees,
Diſcretions, wits, diſpoſures, callings, places,
Indowments, faculties, and all alike;
Since one hath fail'd, I affect all as any, any as one.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: For example, Ile teach thee how to love
The loathed'ſt Creature; Marry I muſt turne Poeticall.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: Nay I muſt be in rime too.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Then, thus I doe begin;
Diſſemble every fault in their Complexions.
And take no notice of their imperfections:
Andromeda was belly, ſides, and backe
To Perſeus ſeene, he did not tearme her blacke;
Andromache was of too large a ſtature,
One loving Hector praiſ'd her gifts of nature.
To her whoſe skin was blacke as Ebone was
I have ſaid ere now, Oh, 'tis a Nut-browne Laſſe.
Or if ſhe lookt a ſquint (as I am true
So Venus look'd) if ſhe be bleake of hew;
Pale, for the World, like Pallas; be ſhe growne
By Iove, Minerva up and downe.
If ſhe be tall, then for her height commend her,
If ſhe be leane, like envy terme her ſlender.
She that is puff'd like Boreas in the cheeke,
Is but full fat, and Daphne ſhe is like.
She that is Dwarfiſh, name her light, and quicke;
And call her well ſet, this is grubbed thicke.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Is this your Leſſon? curſe upon that Tutor
That read you this damn'd Leſſon.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: This was Ovid; how approve you theſe his precepts?

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: I could inſtruct you in a Thouſand ſuch▪
And never trouble Memory.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: To what the poxe, will this your practiſe bring you?
In theſe dayes men doe ſell their Lands, their Fortunes,
And their Eſtates to purchaſe them diſeaſes.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Provide me a good luſty Laſſe to night,
I purpoſe to be merry.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: I care not of what humour, face, or feature,
So thou canſt find one impudent enough;
Search all the Allyes, Spittle, or Pickt-hatch,
Turnball, the Banke ſide, or the Minories,
White Fryers, St. Peters Street, and Mutton Lane,
So thou canſt find one to diſgrace her ſexe,
She beſt ſhall pleaſe my Pallat,

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: He hath ill taſt, that loves to feede on Carrion.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Get me likewiſe a noiſe of Fidlers, and a ſupper too,
Equall with that which old Vitellius made,
When Art would exceed Nature; had I beene he
And had his rich Exchequor, I would have fed
On nothing but Earths choiſeſt rarities,
Drunke nought but Pearle diſſolv'd.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Pray ſir a word:
Can this world laſt ever? you ſell, and ſell,
But when the mony is ſpent, are you reſolv'd
To feede on Huskes, and Acornes? I am plaine,
How many monthes did your old Fathers ſpend
To purchaſe that you in few houres conſume?
Ha, doth this ſtartle you? I am truſty Roger,
And ſo you ſtill ſhall find me: did he compaſſe
That competent Eſtate he left to you
By Fidlers whores, and Cheaters? looke you big?
Nay ſir, I can affront you; where be now
Thoſe furniſh'd Tables, whoſe long backes bid bend
With Chines of Beefe, and Chargers, feaſting both
Neighbours and ſtrangers? are they
Ryotted on lifts and whiflers?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: If none be gall'd, you have no cauſe to wince,
But if you be, then Figo.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Then doe not interrupt me: Baudes and Whores,
Panders and Pimpes, did he keepe ſuch about him?
I hope none here are touch'd; call him to mind, ſir,
And thinke upon his worthy memory,
And how you looſe your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: My ſervants ſervant? ſlave, fetch me ſtraight a Whore.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: An Office fit for none but ſlaves, I am none;
You had beſt bid theſe that are acquainted with them.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: Theſe are Gentlemen, my friends, and my Companions.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: If they be Gentlemen, let them ſhew them ſuch,
That is t'abhorre thoſe vices you are wrapt with.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Ile have Muſicke, and the choiſeſt Cates the Citty can
Afford, and wine in abundance.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: But ſome muſt ſure repent it, when all is gone and waſted

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Pox upon you, we ſhall have you turne Puritan,
Leave big mouth'd Oathes to ſweare by yea and nay:
Th'art not for me, give me a man can roare,
Shew hackes upon his Sword, briſtle, looke big,
Knowes all the Poſtures of a true Duello;
Give and retort the lye in his full nature:
Can weigh and drinke by meaſure all, or halfe
To a rundle, or the circuit of a haire,
Can weigh his drinke as well as meaſure it,
And,
And without frownes or grumbling ſtill attend Ent. Geffry
On my free humours: Geffrey, well return'd, the newes?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: So would my ſword had thee.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.p: A Thouſand pounds brought in to night.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.l: Trifles ſir, acknowledging a Statute, nothing elſe;
'Tis finiſht in a moment.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: And Ile doe it; In th'interim goe, beſpeake us delicates
The beſt and choiceſt, the dearer they ſhall prove
The better they will taſte; Wenches too, Geffrey,
Thou know'ſt my mind, thou ſee'ſt our number.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Unleſſe thy ſelfe wilt make a fourth with us,
And bring (with thee for thine owne appetite)
Some courſer ſtuffe to keepe thee Company,
And ſit at the buy Table.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.p: It ſhall be done, Ile be your Mercury.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.l: If any thing to whet dull appetite,
To heighten pleaſure, and inflame delight
Be this night wanting, ere Sun riſe to morrow
Caſhiere me from your ſervice.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Here's a fellow, whoſe induſtry doth merit double hire,
Of a free Countenance and a light appetite,
When this ſtill frowning grim and ſurly ſir,
Has nothing in his face but melancholly,
And in his tongue repining.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: You'le one day find the difference.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Come Gentlemen, ſhall we to Cardes,
And ſpend an houre at Gleeke?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Game too, all will helpe to ſend a man a going.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: Faith Twelve pence if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: And ſo is he too, to be gleek'd of all.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: What, will you pleaſe to attend us ſome few houres,
In abſence of your fellow?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Yes, ſo there be no whores in Company,
But rather then feaſt where they ſhall domineere,
And bold Rampalian like, ſweare and drinke drunke,
Ile feede on Cheeſe, and Onions; and in ſtead
Of healthing, quench my thirſt with frighted water.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: I will not haunt him as the Divell doth,
But for once I will dogge him. Exeunt all.

div.head: Scaene. 1.
div.stage: Enter Changable, his Wife, and Anne.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Unleſſe your wit were gray as wel as your haires;
You grow in yeares, and ſo you ſhould in wiſedome.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: Taxe my wit? a woman too, to do't?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Did you never ſee a bare face teach a beard?
It is no newes in this ſo pregnant age.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: An Age indeed, when ſmockes muſt read to britches;
Goe to wife, thou ſeek'ſt to make us two that ſhould be one,
Inſtead of me, th'art wedded to thy will;
I feare we ſhall repent it.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: But I ſay, ill, ill woman.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Why I pray?
Becauſe I ſeeke the advancement of our houſe?

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: I would not build ſo many ſtories high
On ſuch a weake foundation, leſt the Garret
Rear'd on ſuch thin ſupporters ſinke it ſelfe into the Celler.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: One of your gravity? I am aſham'd, a Juſtice by
Your place, and can appeare ſo partiall to your owne;
Whom ſhould your providence deviſe to raiſe,
If not your owne? will you be twice a Child?
And now, in this your ſecond infancy,
Not take care for your Cradle?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: Why then I am no ſheepe.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: It ſhould be then your care to ſee me better pleaſ'd.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I pray, good mother, nay, ſir.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: Sir me no ſirs, I am no Knight nor Church-man,
There is a third, make me not that by breaking of my faith.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Thinke what it is to have a great Lord call you
Father in Law, and ſo your Daughter a great Lady.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: So; I had rather ſee her a good Gentlewoman,
Lawfully great in belly and in purſe,
Than ſwell'd with poyſon'd Titles; it to me
Appeares no better than a Timpany,
A griefe not eaſily cur'd.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: His Lordſhip will be here, give him good face,
And curteous Language, or Ile make your boord
As loud as a perpetuall Goſſips feaſt,
Or a diſcourſe of Fiſh-wives; and your Bed
As if you were to lodge in Loth-bury
Where they turne brazen Candleſtickes.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: So you are like to finde it.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: Gentle wife, have patience, and be quiet, Ile give way;
I never heare thy tongue in this high Key,
But I ſtill thinke of the Tower Ordnance,
Or of the peale of Chambers, that's ſtill fir'd
When my Lord Major takes Barge, I will doe any thing,
Good wife pleaſe thy ſelfe, and I am contented.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Why well then: Might not this time much better
Have bin ſpent, t' have taught your Daughter rudiments
Of State? her poſtures, and decorums, fine French Congees,
And quaint out-landiſh Garbes? one that hath bin
A Courtier in his youth, and brought nought thence?
Fye, fye; I am aſham'd of't.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Looke to the Gate there; me thought I heard one knock.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: And comes, it ſeemes, to ſee my Ladyſhip;
I feele ſtate come upon me; ſpeake good Mother,
How ſhall I beare my ſelfe?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Why ſuch at firſt, as you muſt be hereafter; like a Lady.
Proud, but not too perverſe; Coy, not diſdainefull;
Strange, but yet not too ſtraight; like one that would,
Were ſhe well woed, but yet not to be won,
Without ſome formall Court-ſhip; had it beene
My caſe, my wench, when I was yong like thee, Enter Lord Treatwell.
I could have borne it bravely. See, hee's come,
Husband, your Duty; Girle, your modeſt bluſh,
Mixt with a kind of ſtrange, but loving welcome;
Were I as young as once: Your Lordſhip Sir,
Hath done my Houſe much honour.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: Your Mother ſir, that muſt be.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: I make bold,
And like a rude intruder, preſſe upon you
Sudden, and unawares.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Sir, I deſire your more familiar love,
Whom I ſhall ſtudy hereafter to reſpect
According to your worth and gravity.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: You crave his love whoſe ſervice you Command.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I have ſeene a Thouſand private Gentlemen
Both better fac'd and featur'd.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Mrs. Anne, for ſo your name was given me.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Nay kiſſe better,
Beſides, he hath the marke of an ill liver,
He hath not a Noſe ſtrong enough.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: You ſee ſir, what homely entertainement,
And how courſe our poore Houſe can afford you.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Were it baſe,
But 'tis much better then I yet deſerve,
That face alone would make and dignify't;
Your Welcome I approve, good ſir, a word:
Nay, Maſter Treatwell, you may witneſſe it,
We doe not trade in ſecrets.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Troth I felt no more honour from his lippes
Than from another man, nay ſcarce ſo much;
For Slightall kiſſes better.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I tell you as I finde; his Lordſhip? good now
Tell me, in what place of his body lyes it?
If in the face or foot, the Crowne or Toe,
The Body, arme, or legge, the backe, or boſome,
Without him, or within? I ſee no more
In him than in another Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Part of it lyes in what he left behind,
Obſervance, ſtate, retinue, and attendance,
Of which you muſt partake.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Lord, who'de have thought it?
Would he had ſent that part of his Lordſhip hither,
And ſtay'd himſelfe behind; but where's his honour?

sp.speaker: Wi,
sp.p: Do'ſt thou not ſee him there?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: How caſt thou foole? his Nobility lyes in his blood,

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Yes, if his Lordſhip live in that▪
Would you match me to a thing inviſible?
Where I beſtow my ſelfe Ile ſee and feele,
And chuſe to my owne liking.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: So you would make me; this is but a man,
And I can find a man to my owne liking and never trouble him.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: This fooliſh baggage will croſſe all we would compaſſe.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: I am plaine ſir;
I have not much to give, yet I would ſtretch
My utmoſt, to my poore ability,
To ſhew my ſelfe a Father, what ſhe wants
In meanes ſhe hath in Gentry; that my blood
Can witneſſe for her: ſomething too beſides
Though not ſufficient to ennoble her,
Yet ſtill to make her a good Gentlewoman,
And that's all my ambition.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: And that's all I can demand.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: Provided ſtill, all be with her conſent,
For Ile force nothing, wer't from a ſtranger,
Much leſſe from my Childe.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: There's no condition you have yet propoſ'd
But warrants grant, they are ſo reaſonable.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Till now I had thought, your Lords, and Noble men
Had bin poſſeſſ'd of many worthier parts,
Where meaner men are ſcanted; but I ſee
All's one, or little difference.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Miſtris Anne, it were ſuperfluous to begin a Suite
Which hath before beene entred; and I know
Made knowne to you ere this; I come not now
For motion, but for anſwer: All thoſe honours
Titles, and Dignities conferr'd on me
We likewiſe doe communicate with you.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: Which ſhe is ready to accept.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Good mother, 'tis me, not you, whom this affaire concernes:
You gave your owne free anſwer to my Father,
So give me leave to doe where I affect,
The good or bad is mine; not touches you
That are diſpoſ'd already.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: My good wench, I doe commend thee for't.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: No more wife, I have done.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: Or I ſhall but begin. My Lord, proceed.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Court Ladies I have often ſeene and tryed,
Faire Country Damſels, Virgins of choice beauty,
Bred from the City Scarlet, and 'mong theſe
I might have made my choiſe, but all relinquiſh'd
To place affection here; what comfort▪ Lady?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Faith little in that name:
Title my Lord, is a cold Bed-fellow,
And many ſtudy ſtile that marry cares;
Can honour helpe in Child-birth? or Nobility
Us priviledge from throwes?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Why Ceremony;
The gift of Princes, and the pride of States,
Regard in the Weale publicke, and imployment▪
Reſpect, and duty.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Which from his preheminence
Muſt by meere conſequence redownd to you.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: You talke like an old woman, not like one
That ſhould make her firſt choiſe, as I muſt now;
When I am griev'd, can honour cure my heart?
If diſcontent, can my Nobility
Give eaſe unto my Corſives? when your Lordſhip
Is with your Trulls and Concubines abroad,
Where is my loving Husband then at home
To keepe me warme at midnight?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Sir, that's the thing I doubt.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Could you not lend your Lordſhip to a friend,
And keepe the man your ſelfe?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: To a poore Gentleman, one Maſter Slightall,
Who, had he but that ſlight Addition,
I gladly would embrace.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Therefore to ſhew me ſerious, Noble man,
I take my leave thus gently.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: That's no anſwer; Why Nan, why Minion, good your
Lordſhip, take nought in ill part; a peeviſh thing,
God wot, that wants a little tutering.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Slightall quoth a? if ſhe ſlight all as ſhe hath ſlighted me,
Shee'le fright hence all her Suters.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Still will you prate? wil't pleaſe your honour, take
Such cheere as this our ſuddaineneſſe affords?
And there's no queſtion but ere dinner's done
This Tempeſt will blow over.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Ile take your kindneſſe,
Hee's no good Souldier that at firſt repulſe
Will leave the Breach; belike ſhe's faſting now,
Ile take her in full ſtomacke.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Pleaſe you enter?
Attendance for his Lordſhip. Exeunt.

div.head: Act. 2. Scaen. 2.
div.stage: Enter Ʋſurer, and Scrivener, with writings.

sp.speaker: Scri.
sp.p: As faſt as waxe and witneſſe can make good.

sp.speaker: Scri.
sp.p: Yes, and as great an uſe as e're you lent out mony on.

sp.speaker: Ʋſu.
sp.p: Is there no hope he will redeeme't at all?

sp.speaker: Scri.
sp.l: Redeeme this did you ſay? tuſh, had he more,
More he would ſoone ſend after; why hee's all expence and riot.

sp.speaker: Ʋſu.
sp.l: I ſhall love expence and riot while I live;
Not in my ſelfe, I muſt confeſſe, but in ſuch prodigalls
By whom we Uſurers profit.

sp.speaker: Ʋſu.
sp.l: So let him, what he hath;
But this Ile looke to ſafe as my life.

sp.speaker: Scri.
sp.p: He minds nor cares for nothing.

sp.speaker: Ʋſu.
sp.p: For this he minds not, my care is tooke already.

sp.speaker: Scri.
sp.p: Troth hee's ſinking, hee's up to the necke already.

sp.speaker: Ʋſu.
sp.p: May he drowne for him that holds him by the Chin.

sp.speaker: Scri.
sp.l: Alas poore ſheepe, each Bramble ſhares his wooll.
Till hee bee fleec'd quite.

sp.speaker: Ʋſu.
sp.l: What makes he then 'mongſt Bryers? this be his comfort,
His fleſh will ſhew the better when hee's ſhorne,
Hee'le make ſale for the Shambles.

sp.speaker: Scri.
sp.p: Oh theſe Dice, Drabbs, and Drinke?

sp.speaker: Vſu.
sp.l: Excellent ſokers, brave pills to purge the purſe:
But for my part, I will take no ſuch Phyſicke.

sp.speaker: Vſu.
sp.l: Marry, firſt home, and ſafely locke up theſe,
Then ſeeke ſome other new come to his Lands,
To make like prey on him.

sp.speaker: Scri.
sp.l: I am your Scrivener, and ſir, I hope
You'le not forget my paines?

sp.speaker: Ʋſu.
sp.l: Forget thee? no, not whilſt thy Parchment laſts:
I doe remember thee by thy ſhop, thy ſigne,
Yes, thou haſt Labells hanging at thy doore;
Thou writ'ſt a good faire hand, and haſt in Horne,
Sixe ſeverall Seales with ſundry ſtrange inſcripts
All joyn'd together; thee? not remember thee?
I can call thee by thy name.

sp.speaker: Vſu.
sp.l: Money from me, thy writings are all paid for,
It came from Slightalls purſe.

sp.speaker: Vſu.
sp.l: Brokage indeed hath ſome dependance ſtill
On Uſury, and Uſury on that,
Th'are Relatives; one is not called a Son
That hath no Father, and no Father's he
That hath no Son; yet money doth goe hard.

sp.speaker: Scri.
sp.p: Yet let me have my due.

sp.speaker: Ʋſu.
sp.l: Yes, give the Divell that,
For he will have't at length; ha, let me ſee,
Come, let us once be mad, we'le to the next Taverne,
And there debate the buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Vſu.
sp.p: Yes, for this once, not uſe't.

sp.speaker: Scri.
sp.p: A Gallon ſir, betwixt us two?

sp.speaker: Vſu.
sp.l: An Uſurers Gallon, that's juſt halfe a pint,
'Tis none of Slightalls meaſure, 'tis too great,
And come, good Scrivener, write it in Record,
That I am now thus liberall.

div.head: Act 2. Scaen. 3.
div.stage: Enter Slightall, Roger, and Geffrey.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: You have ſerv'd me long, what have you got by me?

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.l: Good Wine, good Victualls, Liveries;
And the countenance of a good Maſter.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.p: That's as your worſhip ſhall be pleaſed to call it.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: So pleaſe you ſir, I ſhall;
That which I thinke y'are brought to now your ſelfe,
Or within little of't.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Thy plaines I commend, thee and thy wit,
That canſt give nothing name, ſuch is my ſtate;
Yet out of this confuſed lumpe of nought,
That which no man of ſence can ſay it is,
Or Title by the name of any thing,
Something I have extracted, and reſerved
For you, for you my ſervants; take this Gold.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: Why, all this alas is nothing.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: To me it is not, for now it is yours,
And may it ever after ſomething prove
To you and your ſucceſſion, as a Stocke
To thrive and proſper by; I onely was,
But am not now; however be you ſtill,
And may this give you Eſſence.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Pray keepe mine,
Your ſervice ſir is all the heritage that I expect from you.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Thou never waſt one that did ſeeke to husband my eſtate,
Which I have vainely waſted; juſt, and honeſt,
In all my looſe deſignes did'ſt counſell well,
And ſtill perſwadeſt me to providence,
That thrift of which I was uncapable,
Employ it to thy owne ends; had it bin more,
Greater had bin thy ſtocke.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Ile keepe it ſir, as Steward to your uſe, but
Alwaies ready to furniſh your leaſt wants.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Though thou waſt ever Pander to my luſts,
And gav'ſt me Spurres to all my vanities,
Fedd'ſt on my riots, and my looſe exceſſe,
Encourag'ſt ſtill to ſurfeits, prayd'ſt not for me
But ſtill prey'ſt on me Geffery; yet, becauſe
Thou once did'ſt claime dependance on my love,
And did'ſt me ſome ſlight ſervice; ſtill report
Thou had'ſt a bounteous Maſter; ſo farewell both.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.l: If this he all, as where no more is left
What more can be expected? this's my portion,
Ile husband't for my ſelfe; he that gets this,
Or part of this, muſt have more ſhare in me
Than either man or Maſter.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Adieu good fellowes, report y'have left a cleane
Gentleman, without or meanes, or mony.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.l: And my neglect; ſo I be ſtor'd my ſelfe,
Which hand with him goes forward.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: A woman; that inconſtant Feminine Sex, Exit Rog. & Geffry.
That changes humours oftner than the Moone
Waynes, or ſupplyes his Orbe: that moving Creature
Hath beene my quicke ſubverſion:
Had ſhe prov'd firme; for her I had husbanded
All that I now have laviſh'd; but too late,
What ſhall I now doe! travell? who ſhall furniſh me?
What comfort can there be to beg abroad?
Or make my ſelfe a ſtorme to forraigne Nations,
After I too much have bin toſſ'd at home?
Ile prove my kindred; kindred he hath none
That hath not in his purſe to ranke with them.
My Kindred waſted, as I ſpent my meanes,
Want makes me a meere ſtranger: then my friends,
There's no ſuch name for him whom need compells
To ſuch extreames as I am newly falne:
Reliefe from them, ſuch as in Cakes of Ice
To him, whoſe Nerves and Arteries are ſhrunke up
By bitter winters fury: then behold,
I here expoſe me to the fate, and force
Of all diſaſters threaten me; I am ready
With a pinch'd ſtomacke, and cold Arctos breath,
With a bare breaſt, armed with patience
Againſt the ſharpeſt ſtorme, and thin neceſſity;
T'encounter with the keene and piercing fangs
Of what want can inflict on my poore Carkeſſe.

div.stage: Enter Anne

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Let Father frowne, or movingly intreat,
My Mother chide, or threaten menaces,
Raile till her Tongue, that yet was never tyr'd,
Cleave to her Roofe in midd'ſt of her exclaimes:
Let my ſpruce Lord cogge in his courtly termes,
And woe me with a thouſand vaine proteſts;
Not all my Fathers hate, my Mothers fury,
Nor all his Alphabet of Stiles and Names,
Could they a Sheep-skin fill, ſhall me divert
From that which I have vow'd, to ſeeke him out
And proſtrate my firſt love.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: The Divell, hee
My mind ſuggeſts when all my meanes elſe faile;
That Bug-beare will ſupply me.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: I am not yet provided friend, not yet;
Thou tak'ſt me on a ſudden.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: For a She-divell; but I meant not her,
My buſineſſe lyes with him that's Lord and Captaine
Of all the Fiends and fire-brands; haunt me not,
Thou canſt doe me no pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: There can be no more terrour in his looke
Than in the face of my extreame diſtreſſe:
His Viſage cannot be ſo horrible
As my deſpaire; what ſhould I feare then, ha?
An Uſurer may weare Hornes, a Scrivener too,
Should I be more affraide of his then theirs?
I know no reaſon for't.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Man can no ſooner thinke upon the Divell,
But a woman is at's Elbow; truſt me not
I've no affaires with thee.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Leave thoſe vaine thoughts
As Fantaſies of a diſtracted braine;
I come with ſorrow, and repentant teares;
To bring you backe your owne.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Not poſſible,
That's all in Huckſters handling, and canſt thou
Bring it from thence? why the great Divell himſelfe
Can never do't; ſome is diſtribued
'Mong Baudes, and Whores; here Panders have a part,
And Cheaters there a ſhare; Tavernes, and Ordinaries:
But the prime part the Uſurer hath in's Cheſt,
I would 'twere in his Belly: and the choiſe
Of all I had, for which theſe were reſerv'd,
Priz'd by me but as triviall ornaments
T'adorne one Jewell, rated above them,
Higher than gold above the baſeſt droſſe,
And that the Lord hath ſeiz'd.

sp.speaker: Scri.
sp.l: Lord of this Soyle; which I will ne're repurchaſe
After his ſo baſe ſullying.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: What ſayes my Donna Anne, my Lady Serpent
Armed in her golden ſcales? What ſayes Madona?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: That I preferre thy baſeſt poverty
Before all glorious Titles; give me eare,
And Ile redeeme thy former injuries
With ample ſatiſfaction.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Heare mee firſt;
Backe to your Lord, and if you want reparations,
Firſt fall into his hands.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: It was my folly,
My appetite too childiſh novelty,
Of which I now crave pardon.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Oh woman, woman,
Thou haſt undone me, ſpent me to my Shirt,
Nay beyond that, even almoſt to my ſoule;
For I am circled in with blacke deſpaire,
And know not how to free me.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I can doe't,
And to that end I come; wants thy ſoule comfort?
Behold, I bring you comfort: Is your ſtate
Decayed and waſted? ſee, I offer thee
A ſecond making, all my hopes and fortunes,
I throw on thee; I am poſſeſt of nothing
Of which thou art not Lord.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Lord? there it goes;
And get thee to him, for in rifling thee
He hath robb'd my braine of ſence, my life of meanes,
My ſoule of ſolace, and my dayes of reſt;
Henceforth Ile be a Mad-man, turne as Savage
As thou to me was't brutiſh: Ile ſeeke out
Some fine familiar Divell, and with him
Converſe, when I have left mans company;
Ile make my ſelfe companion with the Night,
And Traffique with her ſervants like the Owle;
Ile take my Lodging in ſome hollow Cave,
Till I be growne ſo out of name and knowledge,
That if I chance but to appeare by day,
Men, Beaſts, and Birds ſhall all ſtand wondring at me;
As at ſome progedy, and point at thee
For this my tranſformation.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Iealouſie, oh what a fury art thou?

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Fury, where? kept it within my boſom I would cheriſh it,
And hugg't as one that I accounted moſt:
Lay't in this hand I'de brandiſh't 'gainſt my ſtarres
And dare them to encounter: lodg'd it here,
Within my eyes, I would out-ſtare the Divell,
The Divell, I the Divell.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: That foule fiend,
Why doe you name ſo oft? oh ſtudy better thoughts,
And ſet him at defiance.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Canſt not endure his name, yet com'ſt thy ſelfe
To tempt me with his Sattin? oh thoſe eyes,
That once appear'd like to thoſe glorious Tapers
That ſpangle Heaven, ſhew like blacke funeralls
The Siſters beare, that blaſt where ere they burne:
Farewell my ruine, my decay and fall,
And what ſiniſter Fate ſo ere I have.
May thy falſe pride b'inſculpt upon my grave. Exit.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Curſe on that pride, that ſuch a hopefull Gentleman
Should in his prime be loſt by that and me;
But who was cauſe? who firſt traduc'd me to't?
My Mother, and that Lord; the ſin be theirs:
Offend they, and muſt ſcape due puniſhment?
Then let me looſe, what womankind beſt armes,
My uſe of Tongue; if but this Pipe hold cleare,
Ile make both curſe them taught me firſt to ſpeake,
And wiſh I from my Cradle had bin dumbe:
My hate to him ſhall in his charge and coſt,
Redeeme the love that I to this have loſt. Exit.

div.head: Scaene. 1.
div.stage: Enter old Frier Bernard, and young Frier Iohn.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: NOw we have paſſ'd our more retired houres
To holy uſes as our vowes compell;
In zealous and Religious exerciſes,
In Viſitation of the weake and ſicke,
To ſtrengthen thoſe that ſtagger with our prayers,
And ghoſtly counſell; now night calls us home
Unto our Cloyſter, there to ſpend the reſt
Of our late houres in thoughts contemplative,
And ſacred Meditations.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Holy Father, I am affraid time hath prevented us,
'Tis now paſt Eight, and, but I much miſtake,
I heard the warning of the Cloyſter Bell,
Which tells us, if we reach not inſtantly
W'are for this night excluded.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Mercy Heaven how ſwift time runs?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: W'are now at Iſlington,
What hope have we to get to Crutched Friers
Before the Gates be ſhut, and the Keyes carried
Up to the Abbots Chamber?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Thou ſay'ſt true, how ſhall we ſpend the night then?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: We'le knocke here
At the next ſigne, the good man I know well,
Of honeſt converſation, of good life,
And yet a boone companion; one that loves
Good company, and to be merry with them.
He, if he be at home, will bid us welcome:
My Hoſteſſe too, a ſweet and ſmooth-fac'd wench,
Courteous and kind, and wondrous well belov'd
Of all her Neighbours; liberall to the Church,
And much commended for her Charity.
Let us not bauke her houſe.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Knocke good Frier Iohn, and begge us a nights lodging.

div.stage: Enter Woman.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: For Charity thoſe that would be admitted.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.p: Charity ſhould be in bed at Mid-night.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: But Devotion ſhould alwayes wake;
Where's the good man your Husband?

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: Hee's gone from home, and that's a reaſon too
We ſhut up doores thus early; ſay, what are you?

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.p: Religious men, and keepe unlawfull houres?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: 'Tis no vaine pleaſure,
Or evill purpoſe that hath kept us out,
But Chriſtian zeale to viſite and confirme
Them, for his ſake to whom our lives are vow'd;
Grant us reliefe and harbour.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: 'Twere ſuſpitious for me, but a lone woman, he abroad,
To entertaine men of your ranke and place,
VVhoſe luſts have all bin queſtion'd, and have drawne
Good women of beſt rumour and report,
Into foule ſcandall; therefore pardon me,
This night you get no entrance.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: My good Dame,
You ſee me aged, and farre ſpent in yeares,
Decrepit, and unfit for dalliance,
And ſhould my youthfull Novice ſtrive t' exceed
His Lawfull bounds, I am neere to counſell him,
But he was never guilty of ſuch thoughts.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Then grant us the leaſt ſhelter, any place,
By or remote, to keepe us from the cold;
Stable, or Barne, if you be ſo provided,
Or any out Roome where's but hay, or ſtraw
To wrap us in till Morning.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Can you be ſo hard-hearted unto men
Of our ſo knowne Devotion?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Grant us this, and you ſhall have the aſſiſtance of our prayers
In all our Trentalls, Maſſes, Dirges, Oriſons,
Your ſoule ſhall be remembred; but if we
Should by your rude remorceleſſe cruelty
Miſcarry in our perſons, in this raw
And ſo bleake cold; the price of our two lives
Muſt be of you exacted.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: Curſe upon them,
No night but this to trouble me in? being ingaged
To better fare by appointment.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Gentle Dame, for reverence of my yeares and gravity,
And for my Covents Order; for my Name
And my profeſſion, grant Frier Bernard this
Harbour from Froſt and Snow.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: VVell Frier, you ſhall,
But this provided, I will locke you up
In a cloſe Garret, and my ſelfe keepe the Key
To avoid ſuſpition; you ſhall have freſh ſtraw,
But other Bedding none, no fire nor Candle,
Beere, Ale, nor any ſuch commodity,
Now in my Husbands abſence; ſo, pray enter,
And this I doe for Charity.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Now Heavens Beniſon fall on thy head, that two
Religious men art ſo obſequious; gentle Novice, be
Civill and much obſervant, 'tis a courteſie
We ſcarce can find elſe where.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: My holy Father,
I know it well; I am preſcrib'd my limits,
Which I am willing with all zeale t'obſerve;
I would we knew our Lodging.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: All neceſſities are ever to bee pardon'd, once, like Horſes,
Let's lodge in our owne Litter; I commend
The womans modeſty, that is ſo curious,
Her Husband being from home, to avoyd ſcandall,
And mens baſe imputations.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: So doe I,
'Tis one of our beſt Dames; but ſee, ſhe comes
To give us entertainement Enter the Woman.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: I have onely a Cock-loft, pleaſe you gentle Friers,
To make beſt uſe of that and ſome freſh ſtraw,
Beſt harbour that my Husbands abſence yeelds
Y'are welcome to.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: We entertaine it gladly,
And thanke you my good Dame, I am for ſleepe,
That's this my nights ambition.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: Pleaſe you enter, but yet no further then Ile locke you in
Ile keepe the Key my ſelfe.

div.stage: Enter Conſtable, with a Bottle of Wine, and Manchets.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: My Watch is ſet, charge given, and all at peace,
But by the burning of the Candle blew,
Which I by chance eſpyed through the Lanthorne,
And by the dropping of the Beadles Noſe,
I ſmell a Froſt; now to prevent this cold,
To which I am ſubject, I have made my Deputy,
Given up my ſtaffe and power into his hands;
My ſelfe intending to ſpend all this night
Here, at an honeſt Neighbours; ſome proviſion
I have ſent in, and ſome I have brought along,
A caſt of Manchets, and a Bottle to
Of the beſt Wine in Turnball, which, they ſay
All London cannot better: Silent all,
None ſtirring neere, Ile knocke but ſoftly for feare
Of waking Neighbours.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: Not too loud, meane time I ſoftly will ſneake downe
The Staires, and ſoftly let you in.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Gramercy wench; the kindeſt loving Neighbour the
Towne yeelds, the Hamlet cannot match her; a ſmug Laſſe,
And one that knowes it too; I would not looſe her
For halfe my ſtate in the Pariſh, while I'me in Office,
She's ſafe as Mouſe in Mill: Oh, are you come?

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: I was in feare you would have broke with me,
But now I ſee y'are currant.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p:
Sweet a kiſſe, and harke in thine eare.
Frier Iohn peepes out above.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Frier Bernard's faſt, he ſnores and ſleepes as
Snug as any Pigge in Peaſe-ſtraw; but my ſelfe
Cannot once cloſe an eye, which makes me wonder
That I am growe ſo wakefull.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Here's to thy good fat Pullet that's within,
Two fine Cheat Loaves were ſent me from the Court,
A Cup of Nipſitate briske and neate;
The Drawers call it Tickle-braine, 'twill do't,
But is the Roaſt-meat ready?

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.p: Piping hot, Ile goe fetch Salt and Trenchers.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Dreame I? or i'ſt ſubſtantiall that I ſee?
Was this your cunning Dame, to locke us up
Like Priſoners, and afford us nought but ſtraw
To feather our neſts withall? not allow us drinke,
Food, nor a Candle, leaſt we ſhould fire the Houſe,
For that is her excuſe; fire on you both,
Have you theſe trickes? yet God a mercy cranny
That I can ſpy all this. She brings in the Pullet.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: Now let's be merry, but in any caſe
Speake not too loud, leaſt we ſhould wake the Friers.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: Two Abbey Lubbers that are lockt up faſt,
Of whom I could not rid me; but I thinke
I have fitted them, they have neither light nor bed,
Nor any other Comfort.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Tuſh, no matter,
What's that to us? Come ſweet, cut up the Pullet,
And after we'le to Bed.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.p: Doe you't, I am no Carver.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Doe you ſtraine curteſies? had I it in fingering
I'de make you both make but a Fridayes feaſt;
Oh how the ſteame perfumes my Noſtrils.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: In faith it ſhall be thine.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.p: If I begin, may I ne're eate more.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Here's a third would do't, knew hee but how to come by't.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Well, ſince you'le force me to't,
I will make bold this once. One knocks at the doore.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.p: If that ſhould be my Husband?

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: You were ſham'd, I quite undone; he knockes againe;
Upon my life 'tis he.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: What ſhall become of me?
Doeſt thou not thinke he'le ſpare an Officer?
But fall on the Kings Image?

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: Now to convey theſe victuals hence, and put out the fire,
Lord Husband is it you? who lookt for you ſo late?
Theſe ſhall into the Cupboord, if the ſmell
Betray's not w'are ſafe.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: I, if my ſwell betray me not.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: I have got ſuch a cold, a cough withall,
I thought I ſhould have dyed; ſtay but a little
Till I have caſt my Petticoate about me,
Ile quickely let you in; the fire's quite out,
No ſigne of any Feaſt.

sp.speaker: Huſ.
sp.p: I'me almoſt ſtarved, prethee make haſt.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: I am comming, good lye cloſe, and if I can get him
Once to bed, I have a tricke to ſhift you.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: I doe feele I had need of ſhift already.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Here's brave juggling?
For this night, Conſtable, I am your Watch;
Oh but the ſmoaking pullet. Enter Hoſt, and Hoſteſſe.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: Lord Husband that you'le venter whom ſo late,
So many Knaves abroad?

sp.speaker: Huſ.
sp.l: I feare no robbing, and for my Carkaſſe, I ſtill beare
About me to defend that, I've travell'd hard to day,
And am very hungry prethee wife ſee what thou haſt in the houſe?

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.p: What, talke of Victuals now? is this a time of night?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: I by my faith, for one that could come by't.

sp.speaker: Huſ.
sp.p: Talke not to me, ſomething I muſt and will have.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: Had I knowne
But of your comming home I had provided,
But now I pray to bed, this cold ſo troubles me.

sp.speaker: Huſ.
sp.p: Cold troubles me, lay me ſome Faggots on.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.p: You ſee the fire's quite out.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: Would houſe and all were fir'd,
So ſome of us were out on't.

sp.speaker: Husb.
sp.l: I would have had ſome company, I had not
Such an appetite to be merry for an houre this ſeven yeare;
That I could tell where to call up ſome good fellow
That I knew, we would not part theſe two houres.

div.stage: Frier Iohn makes a noiſe in the Garret.

sp.speaker: Huſ.
sp.p: Now bleſſe us wife, what noiſe is in the Garret?

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.p: No hurt man; nay, pray will you to bed?

sp.speaker: Hus.
sp.p: Bed me no bedds, Ile know the reaſon of't.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: Two Friers ſhut from their Covents, wanting harbour,
Begg'd lodging with ſuch importunity
They would not be deny'd; at length I pittied them,
And yet to make them ſure, I lockt them faſt
Up in the Straw-loft, and ſee, here's the Key,
Th'are faſt enough for ſtarting.

sp.speaker: Hus.
sp.l: Frier Bernard, and Frier Iohn? th'onely good Ladds
That I deſir'd to meet with; I beſhrew thee
They had no better welcome; goe, unlocke,
Intreat them hither, we will have one cup
To th'health of all their Covent.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.p: Call them up? what time ſhall we to bed then?

sp.speaker: Hus.
sp.l: Time enough, early betimes, nay, quick Nan, Frier Iohn there?
The bonnieſt Lad e're wore portace in a ſtring,
Or mumbled Maſſe, or Mattins; I but wiſh'd
And ſee, 'tis come to paſſe; the other to,
Though he be ſtrict of life, yet will ſometimes
Be merry, if he like his company;
But my kind honeſt bald-pate, Frier Iacke, Enter woman and Friers.
I ſhall be glad to ſee him; welcome faith,
With reverence, Father, to your gravity,
Be not offended if Frier Iohn and I
Be, not exceeding compaſſe, a little merry,
And play with the Pot; fill ſome in.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.p: To your bellies pots and all.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Exceſſe, my Hoſt, can purchaſe no excuſe,
But modeſt mirth, tranſgreſſing not his true
And lawfull bounds, is good and commendable;
Now give us leave to bid you welcome home.

sp.speaker: Huſ.
sp.l: Thankes good Frier Bernard,
Now as I live, would I had ſome good cheere,
No better then I would pay for; but ſhe tells me
There's nothing to be compaſſ'd.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: The worſe lucke; and yet I ſmell a ſupper.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: Not ſo much as a cantell of Cheeſe, or cruſt of bread,
That can this night be come by (for your throates,
Ile rather ſee you choakt.)

sp.speaker: Huſ.
sp.p: But any fare that would content the ſtomacke.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Say you ſo? Ile try what I can doe.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.p: What a leering eye the Frier caſt towards the Cupbord?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Bid my Dame provide Cloath, Salt, and Trenchers.

sp.speaker: Huſ.
sp.p: But Frier Iohn, how ſhall we come by meate?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: For ſuch proviſion truſt to my Art.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: By Art, can that be done?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Oh prophane, and fearefull!
Art Magicke! didſt thou ever ſtudy that?
It is againſt our Order.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: But not as I will order it, feare it not.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: For a Supper, or ſo, but never durſt deale further;
Will you furniſh a Table fit for meate?

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.p: We ſhall have now ſome fooling.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Good Father peace, no hurt to you nor me.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: That's furniſh'd with a ſtomacke.

l.hi: Doemones, et Cacodoemones conjuro vos, ſurgite et venite.

sp.l: No man ſtirre, is the Cloth laid, and all things fit for meat?

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.p: You ſee to pleaſe you, we can doe any thing.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Now let me ſee,
What Chriſtian Climate yeelds us the beſt bread?
Oh, the beſt wheat's in Spaine; what ſay you now
To a couple of Cheat Loves bak'd in Madrid,
And brought into this Chamber?

sp.speaker: Io.

l.hi: All voſtro comando, Aſt • rothe, il pane in h • c camera preſto.

sp.l: Oh, now 'tis done; mine Hoſt, put but your hand
Into that Corner and pull forth two Loaves.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: But ſee what Art can doe.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.p: Pox on the Frier, have you theſe trickes?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: The beſt in Spaine, or Frier Iohn much miſtakes:
Place them good mine Hoſt, behind the Salt.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Peace Father, more will be done anon;
What Climate yeelds the beſt French Grape?
My Spirit whiſpers Orleance Grape's the beſt,
What ſayes mine Hoſt to a pure Cup of Orleance?

sp.speaker: Huſ.
sp.p: Faith I ſay, would I might ſee't.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Ie vou pre Monſieur Aſterothe, once more
A Cup of Divine Claret; no, a Bottle of ſome two quarts▪
Gramercy, thou haſt done't, mine Hoſt, but caſt your eye
Upon that place, and you ſhall find it there.

sp.speaker: Huſ.
sp.p: Moſt admirable, ſee, here's a Bottle full.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: But taſte mine Hoſt, and try if it be right.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.p: Your Divells take you; you know where's the beſt liquor.

sp.speaker: Huſ.
sp.p: Excellent ſtuffe, I ne're dranke better Clarret.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: No hurt to you ſtill, Father.

sp.speaker: Hus.
sp.p: Bread and Drinke? how ſhall we come by Meate?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Let me ſee, there is a Midnight ſupper now ſerved in
At Prague in Germany, where the Emperours Court
Lyes for the moſt part, and ſeldome is he abſent;
Among all all other dainties, ſpeake, what diſh
Deſire you from the Table?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: What ſay you to a Pullet piping hot,
Now ſtanding on the Dreſſer?

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.p: The Divell take all ſuch ſmell-feaſts.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: But once more Ile employ thee, Aſterothe,
For this night no more trouble thee. Veni, aſſiſte,
& in hac re ſuccurre; I ſmell the Pullet
Smoaking, and Sauce unto't.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Somewhere about this Roome, who hath the Key
Of that ſame Cupboord?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Call for it, good mine Hoſt,
You ſee I come neere nothing, uſe faire play,
Saw neither fire nor candle to provide this,
Toucht neither Locke nor Key within your houſe,
But was aſleepe i'th'ſtraw; unlocke mine Hoſt,
See what the Cupboord yeelds.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: A poyſon on thee, would it might prove ſo to thee,
It was never provided for thoſe chopps.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: What finde you there?

sp.speaker: Hus.
sp.l: A hot fat Pullet, newly dreſſ'd and ſauc'd.
I never heard the like,

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: You ſee what Art can doe.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Tell me, Frier Iohn?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Ile talke with you anon, in the meane time
Eate while 'tis hot, 't hath come a pretty Iourney,
And marvell 'tis not cold.

sp.speaker: Hus.
sp.l: Good wine, good bread, good victuals, ſtomacke good,
And all to meete together? nay fall to,
And he be thank'd that ſent it.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: This to me appeares beyond imagination,
Nay, gentle Hoſteſſe ſit.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Many provide good Cates that taſt them not,
Now bleſſing on their hearts.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.p: But curſe on thine, and on thy ſtomacke too.

sp.speaker: Hus.
sp.p: I pray Frier Iohn, what ſpirit doe you deale with?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Aeſtroth, did you not heare me name him?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: One of the foure great Spirits, that have Dominion
O're the foure quarters of the Earth: good Dame,
Me thinkes you doe not eate.

sp.speaker: Hus.
sp.l: Could you not ſhew your Divell for a need,
To one that faine would ſee him?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Oh 'tis too terrible, it would fright us all.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: What, in his terrors? he would make you mad,
Diſtracted and amaz'd, yet, good mine Hoſt,
To give you all content, I could be willing
To ſhew him but in ſome familiar ſhape,
Such as ſhould not affright you.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Have you no Neighbour whom you beſt affect, whoſe
Shape he might aſſume t'appeare leſſe terrible?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Soft, let me pauſe;
It muſt be ſome that ſtill wake at theſe houres,
We have no power o're ſleepers; ſay I bring him
In perſon of ſome Watchman?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Or in the habit of your Conſtable?

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.p: More ſcurvy trickes Frier Iohn, I may live to cry quittance with you.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: But mine Hoſt, reſolve me one thing; ſhould great
Aſterothe appeare to you in your Goſſips ſhape,
How would you deale with him?

sp.speaker: Hus.
sp.p: Why as my friend, my Neighbour, and my Goſſip.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: No ſuch thing; you muſt imagine him what he appeares,
An evill ſpirit, to kicke him, and defie him,
As you would doe the Divell, otherwiſe
When you are late abroad, and we gone hence,
He'le haunt your houſe hereafter.

sp.speaker: Hus.
sp.l: Feare not that,
If kickes and ſpurnes will drive the Divell hence,
Ile helpe to ſend him packing.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: I muſt tell you, 'tis meerely for your owne good,
Appeare Aſteroth, Aſteroth appeare from underneath the bed
In ſhape of Maſter Conſtable; do't when I ſay't, Not yet?

l.hi: Excruciabo te Aſteroth, in jam jam jam apparebis.

sp.l: Now mine Hoſt, either with zeale expell the Divell hence,
Or have your houſe ſtill haunted.

sp.speaker: Hus.
sp.l: Will kickes do't?
Let me alone to conjure him, pox on the Divell,
He hath put me in a ſweat.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: Ile after him▪ and leaſt he ſhould beare downe part
Of the houſe, Ile let him out of doores.

sp.speaker: Hus.
sp.l: Yes, doe good Nan; I thinke Frier Iohn
I have bumbaſted the Devill; thankes for our Supper,
French wine, and Spaniſh Loaves, I never taſted meat
That more contented me.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Ile tell you by the way; no queſtions now:
Now good mine Hoſt we ſee the night quite ſpent
And the bright day ſtarre riſing in the Eaſt;
We'le take our leaves; make much of our good Dame,
And thinke no worſe of your good Officer,
Your Goſſip and your Neighbour, in whoſe forme
Aſteroth ſo late appear'd.

sp.speaker: Hus.
sp.p: Good night Frier Iohn, and holy Father Bernard.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Onely commend us to my Dame your wife,
And thanke her for our Lodging. Exeunt

div.head: Act. 3. Scaen. 2
div.stage: Enter Lord Skales, Treatwell, Roger, and Geffrey.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.l: 'Tis moſt true, you never ſaw a man ſo ſtrang debauch't;
He hath not onely run out all his fortune,
But even his ſences; I had once my Lord,
Some ſmall dependance on him, but his riot
Hath almoſt ruin'd me.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt have't
See, Maſter Treatwell, that his name b'inrold
Among my other Servants; let my Steward
Receiye ſuch notice from you.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Preferr'd already? may I live to ſee thee
Advanc'd ſome few ſteps higher, to the Gallowes.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Yes, one that he did never, nor I thinke ne're will,
Yet a Lord too.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: I thanke you, no; were there no other Maſters
On the Earth, I am no man for you.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Becauſe the laſt I had, I loſt by you, a Man, that
Save his Title, better'd you, or any of your blood.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Long you to have your Teeth pickt? Ile find time
To talke with you hereafter.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: A bold fellow; give him ſcope, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: He was a Gentleman deſcended well,
As ancient as your ſelfe, as well endow'd
With all the gifts of Nature; better tuter'd,
For he could write true Scholler, which few Lords
In theſe dayes practiſe; not ambitious,
Nor yet baſe thoughted, for he kept the meane,
And aimed but at his equall; you in this
Come ſhort of; for you, leſſe noble breaſted,
Have ſtoop'd to your inferiour.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: Nay good my Lord have patience; heare him ſpeake.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Thinke you, you could have better'd him in valour?
He was too full of fire, witneſſe his ſpirit,
Moſt worthy of a Roman Character;
That being oppreſſ'd, and onely croſt in her,
He loſt himſelfe in all things; and ſhall I
Serve him, by whom a graft of his faire hope
Is by his Whale-like Title ſwallow'd up?
And feede at his Boord that hath famiſh'd him
That was my Maſter? let ſuch Sycophants doe't,
That to their Lords affections ſuite their ſervice,
Not to their fames and honours: that can fawne,
Lye, cogge, and flatter, Pimpe, and Pandariſe,
And ſo farewell, good fellow.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: I ſpeake ſir of my fellow, he's now none
For he attends your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.l: This fellowes bluntneſſe
Doth ſomewhat better than at firſt,
Whom wilt thou follow now?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Him, to his Grave, or to his better fortunes;
Bleſſe your Lordſhip. Exit.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.l: I doe not thinke but under that rough brow
Is lodg'd an honeſt heart; they are beſt ſervants
Whom want, penurious neede, and poverty
Cannot fright from their Maſters. Ent. Chan. and his Wife.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Oh Maſter Changeable, how is't with your Daughter?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Peace you, all will be well, I hope; yet peeviſh, but
It will bring plyantnes: 'tis comming on a pace.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: You heare that newes of M. Slightals frenzy, and his undoing?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: And yet your wiſedome would have match'd your
Daughter unto that ſpend-thrift Begger.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: This his ſervant, ſince entertain'd by me hath told me al.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: Vſe you your humours,
And jeſt at his diſtreſſe; but when I thinke
What he hath bin of late, what come to now,
I cannot chuſe but ſorrow; and the more
When I Record the ground of his diſtreſſe;

But my ſoule's cleare of all.
Enter Anne.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I am as cold as Ice, and you a ſcold.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: And thou a ſlave and Pander.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.p: Speake it not, Ile not beleeve it Miſtris.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Faith mother a mad wench, I thanke my ſtarres.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: But Miſtris Changeable, why did you call me theſe?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Stand but in row, and as I am a woman
Ile make all this good; you here, you there,
And every one in order: Firſt, in particuler,
And next in generall I will goe over you.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: A noble Thiefe, that was your Character,
Some by the high way robbe; ſome are Sea Theeves,
We commonly call'em Pirats; ſome breake houſes,
And others ſnap at ſtals; ſome cunningly
Dive into Pockets, whiſtlers, others lifts;
Some are Poeticall Theeves, and ſteale by wit,
One from another plots, and projects, cheates,
And decoyes; but all theſe under Theeves,
And ſteale but petty traſh: but you more great,
Under pretext of your Nobility,
And countenance in Court, have from a Husband
Stolne a contracted and a married Wife;
For Contract upon Earth, in Heaven is marriage;
And celebrate by Angels.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: A gentle foole, ſuch are your patient Husbands,
That yeeld their wives the Breeches.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Is he ſuch? how now bold huſwife, baggage, peeviſh
Thing, rude, diſobedient, apiſh, and perverſe,
Irregular, hare brain'd, harſh and obſtinate?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: You ſee, ſhe need not put me to my proofe,
Her tongue will do't it ſelfe.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I pray your name? Tre. Treatwell.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Take but the two firſt letters from your name,
I tak't, 'tis Eate-well.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.p: But all this Miſtris, makes not me a Pander.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: No, but when thou firſt was't baſe Baud to the riots
Of thy firſt Maſter, thou mad'ſt thy ſelfe ſuch.
But now in generall let me ſee;
The Prince is not without his flatterer,
The Noble man his Secretary,
The Lawyer his Attourney,
The Juſtice his Clarke,
The Phyſitoan his Apothecary,
The Uſurer his Scrivener,
The Extortioner his Broker,
Nor the Lady cannot be without her Gentleman Uſher;
Your Citizens Wife her Iourney-man,
Your Country Wench her Sweet-heart,
Your Tobacco woman her Pipe-maker,
And every Whore her Pander.
Farewell Geffry; God be with you Gentle-folkes. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Nay good ſir ſpare your teares,
She hath hit us all alike; this her ingeniouſneſſe
Adds to her beauty, not detracts at all;
I love her nere the worſe, nor any here
Whom her diſcourſe hath touch't: 'tis witty frenzy,
And no malicious cancor; ſo I take it:
Nay grieve not you good woman, whom e're long
I hope to Title Mother; doubt it not, all ſhall be well.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Let not that ſticke in thy ſtomacke, never could'ſt thou
Light on a more faire and ſweet Godmother,
To give thee a name; Ile have all friends, let's in,
And comfort the ſad Gentleman, and after to ſupper.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.l: Where I'le try how neere of Kin I am to this
Gentleman, and ſhew my ſelfe an Eate-well. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaene. 1.
div.stage: Enter Slightall Melancholy.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: APiſtoll, Poniard, Poiſon, or a Cord,
The leaſt of theſe would doe't; nay, my owne want
Had I the patience but to ſtay,
The time would end me, for ſince Charity late is dead,
How can beggers live? Death is the eaſieſt
Of any thing on Earth for man to compaſſe;
Almoſt no object but doth offer it:
Fire, Water, not a Stone we ſtumble at;
Our very meat and drinke but ſurfeit of't,
It would diſpatch one quickly: I have read
Of one choak'd with a flye; another drinking,
Strangled with the berry of a bruiſed grape,
Another with an haire; what's this life then
We men doe make ſo much of? if a Pin,
A very Haire hath power to take it hence?
Curſ'd fall of man, in whoſe firſt diſobedience
All things on Earth rebell'd, and warre with him:
How many thouſand things hath Fate ordain'd
To ſtop weake natures courſe? and among them,
How few which can preſerve it? which apprehenſion
Makes me that now I more deſire to live,
The more my life's oppoſ'd: If there be Divills,
As all Religion tells us, I deſire
To have converſe and conference with ſome one
The greateſt fiend among them, for by him
My Genius prompts me, either I ſhall raiſe
My ruin'd hopes, revenge me on my foes,
Or end my wretched dayes in this deſpaire.
I could turne Sorcerer, Witch, or any thing
Might I but blaſt her beauty, brave that Lord;
And ſhew ſome power o're my ingratefull friends;
The Divell, I, the Divell; what Muſicke's this? Muſicke.
Deſcends it from the Spheares?
Hangs it in the Aire?
Or iſſues it from Hell? Come where it can
I will attend the Novell.
sp.stage: Enter an Anticke habited in Parchment Indentures, Bills, Bonds, Waxe Seales, and Pen, and Inkhornes, on his breaſt writ, I am a Scrivener. Dances a ſtraine, and ſtands right before him.
sp.l: Ha? What art thou? I am a Scrivener. The Divell thou art.
sp.stage: Enter dauncing another ſtraine, one written o're his breaſt,
sp.l: I am a knave. Stands as the other.
Why point'ſt thou to thy breaſt, I am a Knave?
The Proverbe were not true elſe, for it ſayes, The Divell's a Knave.
Enter a third with this word, I am a Prodigall.
I am am a Prodigall? I was indeed, and thou doſt well to
Mocke me; what fury ſends Hell next?
Enter a fourth with this, I am a Begger.
I am a Begger? yes, I am indeed,
But how the Divell cam'ſt thou by my ſtile.
Enter a fifth with this, I am a Puritan.
I am a Puritane? one that will eate no Porke,
Doth uſe to ſhut his ſhop on Saterdayes,
And open them on Sundayes: A Familiſt;
And one of the Arch limbes of Belzebub,
A Iewiſh Chriſtian, and a Chriſtian Iew;
Now fire on thy ſweet ſoule.
Enter a ſixt with this, I am a Whore.
I am a Whore? yes, and a hot one too,
And had'ſt a helping hand in my confuſion:
Now the ſame bleſſing on thee.
sp.stage: Enter a ſeventh with money Bagges, and this Motto,
sp.l: I am an Uſurer.
I am an Uſurer, Satans eldeſt Son,
And Heire to all his torments; thou haſt ſwallow'd
Yong heires, and Hell muſt one day ſwallow thee.
Enter an eighth with this, I am a Divell.
I am a Divell? good, 'tis the blacke Lad I ſo long wiſh'd to meete.
sp.stage: The Daunce continued, in the concluſion whereof, &c.
sp.l: The Scrivener beares away the Knave; good Morrall.
The Prodigall the Begger; ever ſo;
The Familiſt the Strumpet, not amiſſe;
Oh but the Uſurer ſtill the Divell and all,
Whom I ſo faine would ſpeake with; Belzebub,
If thou haſt any ſufferance here on Earth,
Or limited power o're man, once more appeare
And offer me free language. Enter the Divell like a Gentleman, with glaſſe eyes.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: The Divell Belzebub, whom thou ſo late ſo loud didſt invocate

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: How cam'ſt thou by this ſhape of Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: As if all habits, faſhions, and attires
Were not with me familiar? I ſometimes
Into a Lawyer can tranſforme my ſelfe
To delay Cauſes; then to a Divine,
To deviſe new Sects, Sciſmes, and Hereſies:
To a Taylor for new faſhions: to a Sempſter,
I was firſt Father for this yellow Sterch,
Which did ſucceed the blew; to a Feather-maker
For Gentlewomans Fans, mens ſpriggs, and falls;
Sometimes I am a Page, and daily attend
Upon my Lords luxurious appetites:
Then can I play the Maſter, Knight, and Lord,
And then coyne ſtrange varieties of riots,
Luſts, and exceſſes, never heard before.
Indeed, what can I not?

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.p: It never was my ſtudy, and of all things I onely except that.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.p: Yes, both on ſoule and body, where I am ſuffered.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: How then came all thoſe Pulpit Hereſies
That have with Chriſtians, Chriſtians ſet at odds?
I read to that great Doctor Arius,
That poyſon'd three parts of the Chriſtian World;
There's not a Sectary, nor a Sciſmaticke,
To whom I am not Tutor.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: Can I then taske thee in nothing?

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Thou canſt not — ſtay?
Thou canſt not change affection, nor invert the paſſions of
The ſoule; turne hate to love, and love to hate.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.p: Tuſh, that with eaſe I can.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: And revenge wrongs?

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: One thing more, and I conclude;
Thou canſt not raiſe a man of deſperate hopes
To a full furniſh'd palme; to pay his debts,
And to give freely where he pleaſe to diſtribute?

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: Am I not Titled Prince of all the World?
And lyes there that in this great Univerſe
Excepted from my large Dominion?
Am I not Mammon too, the god of gold,
Soveraigne of all Exchequors, treaſures, mints,
And thoſe rich Mines that ſet the World at odds?
In ſearch of which men hazard dangerous Seas,
Expoſe them to diſeaſes, and ſtrange Climates,
Above their natures: Gold? I am Father of it,
And have it in abundance.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Then from can, I come to will; wilt thou, great
Belzebub, ſo much of thy huge ſurpluſage make mine
As ſhall doe all that I have here propoſ'd?

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: That when thy wiſhes have attain'd effect,
Thou art full handled, haſt paid all thy debts,
And nothing ow'ſt to any, I may then
Moſt freely claime thy ſoule.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Come, ſtrike me lucke; it is a bargaine:
Wee ſhall neede no witneſſe.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: Thy conſcience is a Thouſand, that ſhall ſerve;
Let me but have't confirm'd beneath thy hand,
And my Exchequor's open.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: 'Tis confirm'd; I ſee the Divell yet hath more honeſty
Then hath his Son, the Uſurer; for to him
A man may pawne his ſoule a thouſand times
Ere he can get a penny: but the Father's,
Of a farre more free nature.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: Come, withdraw, we'le
Have't confirm'd within. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 4. Scaen. 2.
div.stage: Enter Lord Skales, Treatwell, 2. Gentlemen, Geffery, and Mistris Changeable.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: But is your houſe ſo haunted?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: How long hath it bin ſo?

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: Ten daies, no more,
Part of that time that Slightall hath bin Mad,
My daughter paſt her ſences.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: No, onely one by Chamber ſtands remote,
And in that after Midnight there's a noiſe,
That troubles the whole houſe of howlings, ſhrickes,
Fire-workes and Crackers, as if the great ſquib-maker
Were new come from beyond Sea.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: Onely my deſperate Husband, who, one night,
Would be ſo fooliſh venturous as lodge there,
But did returne ſo frighted, told ſuch wonders,
Still fright me to remember.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.l: 'Tis moſt ſtrange: ſure 'tis ſome vex'd ſpirit that hath
Deceaſ'd of late from out the houſe: who dyed laſt in that Chamber?

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.p: Heaven reſt her ſoule, my mother.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.l: Perhaps hers; who having hid ſome treaſure in her
Life time muſt, till that be diſcovered, walke of force,
The like I have read in Legends.

sp.speaker: Gen. 1.
sp.l: It hath bin common, though not in theſe dayes
Frequent, might I adviſe, I would ſeeke out for ſome
Religious man to exorciſe the Spirit, and by that meanes
To baniſh thence the viſion.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Counſail'd well; there are in towne 4. ſeverall ſorts of Friers, white and blacke Friers, Gray Friers and crutched Friers.

sp.speaker: Gen. 2.
sp.l: Good, you call to my remembrance
Among them, one expert in the Art of Necromancy,
His Name Frier Iohn, whom Iſlington hath
Made famous through London.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.p: Him I ſaw but now croſſe by the doore.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Good Geffrey finde him out, and gently intreat him hither,
But acquaint him not with the cauſe.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: But hath he done ſuch ſtrange things?

sp.speaker: Gen. 2.
sp.l: Wondrous ſir; he can tranſhape his ſpirits, if fame
Lye not, into what forme he pleaſe, to imitate me,
