Or perſonate you; he could produce a Divell
In ſhape of this good ancient Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Gen. 2.
sp.l: H'hath done't in habite of a Conſtable,
And may doe't in a Gentlewomans; for his commons
In the Friers he cares not, he can for a need
Conjure his bread from Spaine, from France his wine,
His dyet from the utmoſt of the Earth,
Thus hath his fame given out.

sp.speaker: Gen. 1.
sp.p: Would we might ſee him to make proofe of his cunning.

div.stage: Enter Changeable, and his daughter Anne.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: And as I told thee Nan, be ſwayed by mee,
Ile make him thine, employ my induſtry,
Counſell and paines, to weane him by degrees
From his wild courſe of deſperate Melancholy:
Ile ſeeke him out, perſwade him, lay thy love
As open as the mid-day: hope in me
And doubt not to prevaile.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Thou knoweſt he loves me; I was ſtill his friend,
And friend with friend what cannot he performe?
Make thy ſelfe mine, Ile croſſe thy Mothers workings,
And foole that Lords attempts; onely be you of a more
Temperate humour, and more ſtay'd, obſerving but what I
Shall project for you, and doubt not my performance.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: You in all things
Have prov'd your ſelfe a Father: Ile henceforth
Strive to expreſſe a Daughter.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.p: Here's now my Husband, he can ſpeake it all.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: But ere I queſtion that, of you, faire Miſtris,
Let me be firſt reſolv'd; is your Braine yet
In a more ſetled temper?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Sir, it is; me thinkes I am new wakened from a
Dreame, in which I long have ſlumbering loſt my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I am, thanke Heaven, and my good
Fathers counſell and advice.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: I held it wife, a deed of charity, & did it for the Lords ſake.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Sir, henceforth I ſhall obſerve you better.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: You now have wreath'd me with a Crowne of hopes.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: Made me againe thy Mother, and this worke,
Your ever patient and obedient wife.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: Marry Heaven continue it wife, 'tis but need;
In conſcience thou haſt bin froward long enough.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.l: Theſe things ſo well ſucceeding, pray reſolve us
In what forme doth this Divell haunt your houſe.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: So I told you, ſure your Mothers.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: Troth ſhe was ſomewhat ſhrewiſh like my wife,
But yet I thinke not hers.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: This apparition was the full portract of a young beautious Lady.

sp.speaker: Gen. 1.
sp.l: A harmeleſſe Spirit faſhion'd from the Aire,
And yet aſſuming ſubſtance, ſhape and forme,
That where ſhe loves, doth all the Offices
Of a faire Lady: can ſupply with gold.

sp.speaker: Gen. 2.
sp.p: And all things to man uſefull.

sp.speaker: Chan
sp.l: So I have heard; but this cannot be ſhe,
For this had with her beauty ſo much terrour,
So much affright and horrour in her lookes,
Such a confuſed noyſe, with helliſh ſounds
Able to drive the ſences retrograde;
Turne reaſon into madneſſe, and invert
Capacity to fury; that, I vow
I would not to be heire of all the World
Endure like night againe. Enter Geffrey & Frier Iohn.

sp.speaker: Gen. 2.
sp.p: Here comes the Frier, the man can beſt inſtruct us.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Haile Gentlemen, this man that ſtands at Livery
And ſaith he doth belong to a great Lord.
Hath partly by intreates, part by command,
Enforc'd me from my meditations backe
To know his Lordſhips pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Welcome Frier, 'tis told us thou canſt exorciſe a ſpirit,
We have employment for thee.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Expect you ſuch things from religious men,
And of our holy Order?

sp.speaker: Gen. 2.
sp.l: Come, we know you are an Artiſt in that hidden skill,
And have commerce with mighty Aſterothe,
That great Arch Divell.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Now mercy Heaven who hath ſeduc'd you thus?

sp.speaker: Gen. 1.
sp.l: Come, come we know it,
And this withall; in what men are moſt expect,
In that they are moſt dainty, and ſo you;
In Dauncers and Muſitions 'tis found true;
Of all men, where they are moſt excellent,
They are moſt curious to expreſſe their skill,
So no queſtion, you.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.l: Remember Iſlington, my Hoſt, my Hoſteſſe, and the Conſtable,
Should we be ſilent, every Oyſter-wife,
Fiſh-wife, and thoſe cry Milke and Orenges
Can ſpeake of your rare ſupper; fye, Frier Iohn,
And ſo dainty to your friends?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Either I muſt take upon my ſelfe, and by ſome tricke evade it,
Or elſe ſhame that which I have done before.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: As you would purchaſe us your laſting friends.

sp.speaker: Gen. 1.
sp.l: Or make us at our deaths,
Give Legacies unto your holy Couent.

sp.speaker: Gen. 2.
sp.p: Come, we know what you can doe, good Frier.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: What, you make me a Conjurer?

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.p: A man of Art, no more; ſo much we know you are.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: His houſe is haunted by a wicked ſpirit
Which we would have you by your Art remove.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: To lodge one night within the Chamber,
And know of it the cauſe of its diſturbance,
Or what might be the will of the deceaſſ'd,
Which knowne, and being performed, the troubled Ghoſt
Might reſt in peace.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Lodge where the foule fiend walkes?
A propper jeſt t'expoſe me to ſuch danger,
So I might come to juſtifie the Proverbe,

l.hi: Where had the Divell the Frier, but where he was;

sp.l: But I muſt face it out: Pray Gentlemen, which of you all
Hath ſeene that Viſion? in what ſhape walkes it?

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: Like a woman ſir, but with ſuch horrour
And aſtoniſhment, I tremble once to ſpeake't.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: And I to heare't.
What a ſhee Divell now? for all the World
I would not once affront her; bring me hither
Ten thouſand male Fiends, I could charme their tongues
Before one Female fury.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: Sure this Frier is wittily conceited?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Had it bin great Belioth, Aſteroth, or Belzebub,
I durſt affront them, and confront them too,
Oh but the Divells Dam; why againſt her
There is no Prayer, no Spell, no Exorciſme;
No Circle that can hold her: But appear'd ſhe
Wrinckled in Brow or faire and beautifull?

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: As lovely to the view as flouriſhing May,
Clad in the pride of Spring.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: So much the worſe,
Well wot you that our Order is by Oath
Confin'd from any meeting with that Sex,
Eſpecially at Midnight; and ſo late;
Scarce in the day-time durſt I meet a face
Of ſuch Temptation, but in dead of reſt
'Twould ſcandalize my Order.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: Preſſe him not, if he be ſo preciſe.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Heavens Beniſon and mine light on you till I meet you next;
But to lye there where a ſhe Divell haunts,
(Leſſe with my Hoſtes by at Iſlington)
May the Grand Divell fetch me, bleſſe you all. Exit.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: Tuſh, Schollers ſtill are Cowards, let him paſſe,
Daughter, you ſtill are mine?

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: Enough; will any of you Gentlemen,
In that my laſt: nights lodging ſecond me?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: 'Tis too full of terrour; Geffrey wilt thou?

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.l: Offer my ſelfe to the Divill before my time?
You might accuſe my folly.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: It ſhall be then my care to finde out one
To conjure downe this ſpirit, and doubt it not.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: So much for that: But Miſtris, what from me,
Except you to expreſſe my gratitude
For this ſo late a favour?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Onely this; t'avoyd all imputation fame may caſt
Upon my honour touching Slightalls fall,
In which the World may thinke I had chiefe hand:
'Tis but to find him out, and on his poverty
Beſtow ſome ſmall reliefe.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Now as I live, Ile doe't with a full and
Plentious hand if that be all.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.l: Ile aide him in the ſearch to make
That ſweet concluſion.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: In the meane time't ſhall be my providence
To have my houſe unhaunted; come my Lord,
Leade you the way, my wife and I will follow.
Remember Nan. Exeunt.

div.head: Act. 4. Scaen. 3.
div.stage: Enter Roger.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Want whil'ſt I have, or heare my pockets chide?
While his are ſilent? there's no juſtice in't:
And if he doe while my Exchequor laſts,
May I be held a Proverbe made to caſt
In every falſe Groomes teeth?

sp.speaker: Scri.
sp.l: Upon my—

sp.speaker: Ʋſu.
sp.l: I will not truſt to heare-ſay, let thine eyes
Proclaime what's written in this Almanack,
If this be the ſet Day.

sp.speaker: Ʋſu.
sp.l: If't be not tendred then 'twixt Sun and Sun,
The Morgage is my owne.

sp.speaker: Scri.
sp.p: If you have the conſcience to take the forfeit.

sp.speaker: Ʋſe.
sp.l: Conſcience? what in that is wanting he ſhall find
Made good in Law.

div.stage: Enter Slightall Gallant, and his Page with Mony-baggs.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: I ſee the Divell yet is good to ſome,
Though it repents me of the Bargaine ſeal'd,
Yet am I glad and proud of my ſupply;
Which the more precious is, being infinite,
Not capable of end; for Mammons treaſure,
A prodigall hand may waſt, but ne're conſume.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: What ſudden change is this? doe my eyes mock me,
Or muſt I call him Maſter?

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Roger? a hand; I know thou art in want, as one ſome
Weekes that hath bin out of ſervice, take that gold
And ſpend it freely, when thou want'ſt here's more.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: And you are both in caſh and ſence likewiſe?

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Why man, 'tis want of mony makes men mad,
For that diſeaſe here's Phyſicke: honeſt Hodge,
Goe thou and ſummon all my Creditors,
Leave not a man to whom I owe, uncall'd,
And pay them to the utmoſt they demand;
Be ſo farre from bating of the Principall,
As pay them all arrerages; 'tis our will
And doe thou ſee't perform'd.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: What's that to thee? have we not here to doe't?
Thoſe Debts that reckoned were meere deſperate
Firſt ſee diſcharg'd, unleſſe ſome certaine Morgage tyed to a day.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Monſieur Damnation? what, are you ſo neere?
I know you ſir, a Thouſand pounds and th'uſe,
Tender the ſumme, there's gold, and bring me backe
The Morgage of my Mannour.

sp.speaker: Ʋſu.
sp.l: I'me undone then: no haſt good
Maſter Slightall, why to morrrow,
Or the next day will ſerve, ſome fortnight hence,
Nay, were't a moneth, I could forbeare the money.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Quindecem Michaelis, you remember that,
I prethee ſee this man firſt ſatiſfied,
And doe't without delay: if he deny
The tender of't Ile have it done in Court;
With ſuch we muſt not dally, quicke, good Hodge:
That once diſpach'd, affaires of greater conſequence
Attend thy truſt and care.

sp.speaker: Ʋſu.
sp.l: If needs I will, we Uſurers are like women
Who conceive with great pleaſure, and are delivered
With great paine; ſo we get our wealth with infinite joy▪
And part with the leaſt of it with infinite torment.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: To any man that can but ſhew my hand,
Or witneſſe where I have but paſſ'd my word,
Pay ready downe, about it, and returne.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: And have we liv'd to ſee the golden age once more?
Now Geffrey, if I meete you I dare affront you boldly.

div.stage: Exeunt. Manet Slightall.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: How want dejects, and plenty cheriſhes?
What a new change perceive I in my ſelfe?
Yet not ſo much in habite as in heart!
The ſight of gold hath ſhooke off all thoſe dumps,
Whoſe Leaden weights were hung upon my ſoule,
To keepe it downe from mounting; and I now
Finde in my ſelfe a free and dexterous ſpirit,

Uncapeable of cloudy Melancholy.
Ent. Lo. Treatwell, & Geffery.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: I muſt, as did my Miſtris late enjoyne,
Paſſe in the ſearch of this ſad Gentleman, and to
His low dejected poverty caſt ſome few peeces.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.l: If his pockets lining ſuite but to the out-ſide
Of his Cloaths, he hath ſmall need of them.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.p: What, growne ſo brave? he hath ſure lighted on ſome cheate?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: 'Twas her injunction, and doubtleſſe
Ile accoſt him; ſave you ſir.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: I would be ſo, but 'tis not you can doe't.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: I underſtood that you were late in want?

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Not of a Wife; but for your Lord ſhips curteſie
I had had one too many, thanke you for it.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: For another? no,
Now much good doe't you with the thing you have,
I have no more to part with.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Leaving that; I underſtand you are a Gentleman
Nobly derived; but withall, y'are poore.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: You will not ſell your Lordſhip?

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Why he that askes the queſtion, I, my Lord;
If you will walke by Land I'me your firſt man,
Ile bid as faire as any.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.l: A Bankerupt idle fellow brave your Lordſhip?
Beate him to's wits, or let me kicke him for you.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Ha, what's that? who, Geffery Codpeice, Iohn Boe Peepe,
Is't you that prate ſo freely? my young Iudas,
Have you conſpir'd againſt me?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Stay, firſt we will debate in friendly tearmes,
Before you grow to out-rage.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Done moſt Lordly; your tongue will grace you
Better than your Sword, 'tis the moſt Noble faſhion.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: I'le be briefe, I underſtood your ſtate was much
Decay'd, which in my honour I commiſerating,
My purpoſe was in ſome ſort to relieve you;
And would you better underſtand your ſelfe,
It might appeare a noble courteſie.
Becauſe it came ſo free and uncompell'd

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Such as one Neighbour to another doth
To get his wife with Child, a courteſie, and ſo it fitly may
Be call'd becauſe it brings him to his Knees.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.l: Still, ſtill miſpriſion; might I adviſe you, proffer
What you purpoſe, and if refuſ'd, ſo leave him.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Counſail'd well: there's twenty pieces for you.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: For a wife? Her Ladyſhip is yours for nought already,
And ſhould I ſell her twice?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: This ſaucy fellow uſurpes upon our patience,
Which we'le puniſh be our ſtrong hand.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: A puniſher, my Lord? what beg the Beadles Office?

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: I doubt his Lord ſhips warrant is not currant, therefore Ile not obey.

div.stage: As they ſtrive to oppreſſe him, Ent. Rog. They 2. beate of the other 3.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Sir, all's diſpatcht, but by my faith I lye,
Here's ſomething here to doe.
Why God a mercy Maſter, I perceive
Your ſpirits not all ſpent.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: Thankes to thy Sword, or I had bin oppreſſ'd elſe.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: But how differ'd you? to be aſſail'd by ſuch a ſhamefull odds.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: They ſcoff'd at my ſuppoſed poverty,
And my great Lord forſooth, as I had begg'd,
Would have beſtowed his guerdon on my want,
Which taking in foule ſcorne, the valiant ſir
Aſſail'd me at theſe baſe advantages:
But haſt thou done as I enjoyn'd?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Moſt carefully; all's to the full diſpatch'd.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: If with the Divell▪ I could diſpence as well,
I ſhould have eaſe within.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Ha, ſirra Geffrey, I
Thinke you plaid at leape Frog?

div.stage: Enter the Divell, and claps Slightall on the ſhoulder.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Doe not demand thy debt before the day;
Thy forfeit is not due yet.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: No ſuch thing; the buſineſſe that I come to treat with thee
Is of another nature.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: To hot for thy acquaintance, doe not aske,
Attend me to my Chamber, whether anon, I will not faile to come.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Too hot, and why? he may be honeſt, but he hath the
Countenance of an old ſubtle knave; well, Ile attend you. Ex.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.p: Have I not kept my word?

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: Stor'd thee with all the ſuppliments
Mans uſe can aske.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: Nay, was not I aſſiſtant in this quarrell, prompting thy
Man to come to thy releaſe, juſt at the inſtant danger:

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: His approach was fortunate and happy.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: Then ſpeake freely,
Did'ſt ever in thy life time meete a friend,
Whoſe word, aſſured truſt, and conſtancy
Could ranke with mine in all things?

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: Never any; but what may this inferre?

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.p: Proofe of thy gratitude, or to be term'd unthankefull.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: Wilt thou in meere
sp.p: Requitall of ſo many, doe to me one faire Office?

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: Firſt propoſe it, and then expect an anſwer.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: There's a houſe haunted with a ſhe ſpirit, one of my
Servants, and Kitchin maides in Hell, employ'd by me
For ſome knowne cauſes, who hath play'd ſuch prankes there
No man's ſo bold dares lodge within the roome,
This bed would I have thee to undertake.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: To ſend me to Hell before my day? your plot is too apparant.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: Still amiſſe; have not I power o're al my creatures there
To limit and command them? art not thou
One of our houſe by Indenture? though to them
Shee appear'd gaſtly, horrid, and deform'd,
To thee ſhe ſhall ſeeme faire and beautifull,
No whit inferiour to that Graecian Queene,
That launcht 1 • 000. Ships from Aulis Gulfe,
And brought them to the fatall ſiege of Troy.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: Make but this good, Ile do't.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: And ſo confirme thee
A Minyon to the mighty Belzebub,
And great in our blacke Kingdome. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaene. 1.
div.stage: Enter Lord, Changables Wife, and Geffrey.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: BUt was he ſo perverſe and peremptory?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: He brav'd neceſſity, and outfac'd want,
And tooke my proffer'd largeſſe in ſuch ſcorne,
As he had bin ſome great Kings Treaſurer;
My bounty he defy'd with ſhaking pockets,
The noiſe whereof deafned and ſeem'd to drowne
The ſound of my deſpiſed Charity;
Some pieces I would willingly have given.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Meerely refuſ'd,
And with a haughty and contemplative ſmile,
Inſtead of gratefull thankes, proudly demanded if I would
Sell my Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: While I could limit patience I forbore,
To chaſtiſe him with an ungentle hand;
But when I found no bounds in his diſtaſt,
But that it ſtill exceeded Law and compaſſe,
I thought to chaſtiſe his ingratitude;
And did it with my Sword.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.l: I thinke we made him fly, for I am ſure ſome there
Gave ſhamefull ground.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: But leaving that,
How doth my Daughter reliſh you of late?
Doe you not finde her comming?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Affible, as any courteous maid alive can be,
To whom I did diſcover theſe proceedings,
Which ſhe ſeem'd well to reliſh.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Doubt not then, all will be to our wiſhes;
One thing onely, which ſadds me when I thinke of't.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: To thinke my houſe ſhould be ſo ſtrangely troubled
In dead of Night.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: And that I feare it is my Mothers Spirit,
Who for ſome unknowne cauſes reſtleſſe walkes,
As one not ſleeping in her quiet grave;
'Tis this that moves me deepely.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: I have ſent
To one Frier Bernand, a Religious man,
And Tutor to Frier Iohn, to learne from him the depth of
This concealement; and ſee, in happy time

Treatwell's return'd
Ent Treatwell.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: Sir, I had conference with him.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.l: By no entreaty or perſwaſive skill,
Nay were he preſſ'd by menace or command,
He vowes to have no hand in theſe deſignes;
I could not make him thinke ſuch things can be;
He counts them meere impoſtures, falacyes,
Or, let a man receive them at the beſt,
Illuſions of the Divell; that Ghoſts walke
He ſaith directly 'tis impoſſible,
And in that faith he'le dye; further diſcourſe
I could by no meanes get him liſten to, but halfe diſpleaſ'd he left me.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: That's his faith, but we are froc'd to credit

Otherwiſe by lamentable proofe.
Ent. M. Changeable.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.l: Here comes your husband, he hath perhaps ſome newes

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: I have bin labouring, toyling and moyling,
To finde the cauſe of this ſo ſtrange diſtemperature,
Queſtion'd Divines, and talkt with cunning men,
With Fortune-tellers, skill'd in Palmiſtry,
Not a tain'd Gipſey can eſcape my ſearch, but I with ſuch
Have Trafficke.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: Troth ſmall, or none yet, moſt in this conclude,
That pretend Iudgement; that till we finde ſome one
To lodge without companion in that Bed,
And in the dead of darkeneſſe queſtion it,
Why, to what end, and for what cauſe it walkes,
The Viſion ſhall continue: this they ſaid,
But none amongſt them all ſo reſolute as to
Attempt th'adventure.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: Not ſo; for comming from the Friery late,
I met a man by chance that croſſ'd my way,
Whom rather too much ſpirit had poſſeſſ'd,
Or too much folly made meere deſperate;
Would willingly attempt it, and indeed
He did intreat it of me as a Suite.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: Becauſe he's mad:
For who of underſtanding, or of ſence,
Would willingly confront great Belzebub,
Perhaps deſpaire, diſtraction, diſcontent
Or fury hath poſſeſt him; be't what will,
VVhat's that to us? his is the certaine danger,
Ours the aſſured gaine.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: One like enough, were Hurcules alive,
With him in Theſius ſtead to enter Hell;
A mad companion whom you all well know,
One that was once a Suter to my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Of all men living I am loath that he ſhould lodge
Beneath my Roofe; were there none ſuch he'de play the
Divell himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: But wee have thoſe
Within, can tame him were he twice ſo wild.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: But he to be receiv'd? of all men living
I doe not love that fellow.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: See your errour,
What better way, more ſecret, and more ſafe
Can we deviſe to be reveng'd, than this?
To have him peece-meale torne by Haggs and Fiends;
He hath no prayer to arme him 'gainſt their aſſault,
His Oathes will be aſſiſtant to their fury,
And further not repell it: You by this
Are from a Rivall freed; my daughter Nan,
From an importunate Suter, Begger too;
We all from a diſturber, and a man
That wrong'd our common quiet.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.l: He ſayes true ſir,
Let all your anger then conclude in this,
And bid the Divell take him.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.l: I know not how you could diſpoſe him better
And empty all your wiſhes.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Well, I am pleaſ'd,
Employ your beſt diſcretions.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: Sicke in her Chamber, where ſhe keepes her Bed,
And dares not thence remove.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: The worſe for her,
Yet for our purpoſe better, as it happes,
Becauſe ſhe ſhall not ſee him, nor he her;
Harke, there's one knocks, 'tis Slightall on my life;
Diſperſe I doe entreat, Ile anſwer him. Within.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Where's this Three-headed Dog that keeps Hell gates?
He knockes that faine would enter.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: 'Tis the ſame,

I know him by his roaring.
Enter Slightall.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: If this, as many men give out, be Hell,
Shew me the Maſter? he that keepes the houſe:
Pluto that great grim ſir.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: I am the Lord
Of this poore Mannour; now, I cannot tell
By what hard Fate diſtreſſ'd.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Oh, you keepe lodgings,
And as I underſtand, the Divell here hath late tooke up his Inne.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: I would for one night be his Chamber-fellow,
Shall I have entertainment, good mine Hoſt?

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: I would not wiſh you ſir.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Wiſh me no wiſhes,
I am the Knight adventurer that would doe't:
One thing reſolve me; hath the Divell your Gueſt
A Horſe in the Stable?

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Then make him pay for's Bed; it is the cuſtome
Of every Inne through England.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: Sir, I know you,
And ever wiſh'd you to your hearts deſire,
How well you may remember; if forgot,
In you 'tis errour, and no fault in me.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Which love I thus have ſtudied to requite,
To conjure hence your Divell; how appeares it?
In Feminine ſhape?

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: But not like Madam Proſerpine your wife?
No ſhape elſe can affright me.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: I muſt confeſſe
A Divell of her tongue, but no way elſe ſir.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: There

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Command me two faire Tapers, that may laſt
And burne out this nights hell.

sp.speaker: Sl
sp.l: Thoſe, my good ſword, this Booke, and my bold heart
Are Guards ſufficient 'gainſt a thouſand ſhadowes
Of no Corporeall eſſence capable.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Some wine too, I entreat,
'Tis the beſt armour to a fainting ſoule,
And then no further trouble.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Whom am I to encounter? ſingly too?
Without a ſecond? ſpirits, or Fantaſmes?
Ghoſts being, or imaginary dreames?
Not in the comfortable day, and view
Of judging eyes, but in the ſolitude
Of melancholy darkaneſſe? Ile not thinke of't, before

I find the truth, or mockery.
Ent. with Wine, Chan.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Indeed I muſt thank you for't? indeed I am your man; now, if you pleaſe,
Leave me to my adventure.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: Reſt may your Body,
And peace poſſeſſe your thoughts.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: What e're betide me.
Good night to you: ſee the doores lockt and bolted,
That's all I ſhall enjoyne you; till we meete
A faire and proſperous Morning: did I know
What object I ſhould meet with, I could then
Fit me unto the plunge accordingly,
And arme me for the Grapple; but of this
I nothing can conjecture: oh but that Parchment
By which I am oblig'd to pay a ſoule,
The memory of that is horrible,
And ſtrikes me with affright: what can I gheſſe,
But that this is my divells Stratagem,
To have his Serjeant death arreſt me heere;
And beare me to that curſed Dungeon, Hell?
An Uſurer would doe't; any fat Serjeant
That lookes as plumpe in cheekes as th'other leane;
Then why not theſe? their gaine's but petty traſh,
But theſe the precious riches of a ſoule;
Yet in theſe Hell-hounds have I greater truſt
Than in thoſe Doggs of th'Earth, for I am ſure
The Divell himſelfe can be no Uſurer,
He is ſo free of his purſe; and hitherto
Hath lent his money gratis: Ile to Bed,
And yet I will not; I'me no whit diſmay'd,
Nor yet at peace within; diſquieted
With ſudden feares, nor yet well reconcil'd:
Ile try if I can ſleepe; and yet not ſo,
Leſt I be taken napping; yet Ile throw me
Upon the Bed and reade.
sp.stage: Ent. Divells dauncing, with Fire wokes, and Crackers.
sp.l: Hey, hey, the Divells daunce, ſure Hell's broke looſe?
And this is their Shrove Tueſday; hornes upon you,
And that's the Cuckolds curſe; yet this was ſport,
Though ſomewhat fearefull: had they proffer'd violence,
This ſhould have thraſh'd among them, but it ſeemes
Theſe were no quarreling ſpirits; yet howſoe're,
I am glad they are gone: what object ſhall be next?
Muſicke? yet this ſounds ſweeter than the firſt,
For that was all of diſcords.
sp.stage: Ent. two Maides with Banquet and Lights; after courteſies to him, they fetch in Anne, and place her at the Table againſt him.
sp.l: What, in Hell are there white Divells, Angels are
Theſe of Light, or but light Angels? Banquet too?
And Feaſt? the furies in the lower World
I thought till now had fed on hot meates all;
On parboyl'd Murtherers, Uſurers roaſted fleſh,
Whores cheekes for dainties, Carbonado'd o're
Red ſulphurous Gridions, and a thouſand ſuch:
But what's ſhe enters now? to whom the reſt
Doe ſuch obeyſance? place her in her State,
As if ſhe were the Queene grim Pluto ſtole,
And great Alcides once redeem'd from Hell?
Be'ſt thou Ghoſt, ſhadow, Fuery, Fiend, or Hag,
Introth thou art a faire one; In Heavens name
What art thou? ſpeake, do'ſt anſwer me in ſmiles?
Why do'ſt thou beckon me? point to thoſe ſhadowes,
As were the meates eſſentiall! had I a ſtomacke,
With thee I durſt not eate: do'ſt laugh at me?
Oh hadſt thou but a ſubſtance to that preſence
I'de dare on thee, wert thou th' infirnall Dam.
Temptation ſtill? Ile thinke her what ſhe ſeemes,
For no affright can lodge in her faire looke,
And venture ſomewhat neere; ſhe's left alone,
And ſingle; I will to her, what would you have me
Sit there? I will; eate? but begin Ile do't:
Faine would I take her by the hand, but feare
Hers rather would melt mine, than melt in mine:
Why ſhould my ſence of touching thus turne Coward?
My eyes being ſo valiant, can you ſpeake?
Oh ſuch a wife through all the world I'de wiſh,
That would be ever Tongue-ty'd; reach your hand?
I would and gladly too; s'foot I will venture,
No danger, a white, ſoft, and delicate palme,
That nigh diſſolves in touching: you feele well,
Sweet, can you kiſſe? moſt ſweet and excellent;
Againe, againe; were there no worſe in Hell,
And this the place, here would I wiſh to dwell.
Nay you that can both touch and lip it too,
Sure can doe ſomething elſe: be'ſt thou a Lamia,
Or Incubus, thou canſt not ſcape me ſo;
I have a ſpirit in me great as thine:
Th'haſt boorded it, Ile ſee if thou • anſt Bed,
And try if thou haſt mettle to thy ſhape;
Dumbe ſpirits cannot clamour out for helpe,

Ile now try Maſteries.
Thundering and howling, Ent. Chan. like the Divell

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Helliſh Fiend thou lyeſt;
But ere thou claim'ſt that debt, ſhew me that beauty
I am ſo much entranc'd with.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.p: 'Tis vaniſht into Aire, whence it was form'd.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: Great Belzebub, yet once more let me ſee't.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: Not poſſible, untill you meet in Hell; ſo neere
Thy Fate, and cannot now the terrour of that place
Coole thy hot courage? ſee the forfeiture,
And here I doe arreſt thee.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Angels bale mee,
Or I am ever loſt.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: That hand I cannot, yet be not Judge and
Accuſer too; Ile put my cauſe to cenſure.

sp.speaker: Di
sp.l: I am content, 'tis done; how ere thy ſoule
I'me confident is won. Exeunt.

div.head: Act. 5. Scaen. 2.
div.stage: Enter Uſurer, and Scrivener.

sp.speaker: Ʋſu.
sp.l: Oh, curſe on that ſupply that ſnatcht from me
So rich a Morgage.

sp.speaker: Scri.
sp.l: You look'd not in the Almanack
For good and evill dayes.

sp.speaker: Ʋſu.
sp.l: Yes, but too late:
For when 'twas paſt, I counſail'd with the day.

sp.speaker: Scri.
sp.p: And pray what was the Motto.

sp.speaker: Scri.
sp.l: Alas poore man, all to no purpoſe, be better advis'd,
Or it may be, kept out of his clutches; theſe, if we may
Beleeve th'Aſtronomer, are omenous dayes.

sp.speaker: Scri.
sp.l: Nihil in Bag? a ſcurvy criticall Embleme,
Preſaging empty pockets, Why no Cutpurſe
Will trade when that's in power; then why would you
Lend money in that unlucky houre?

sp.speaker: Ʋſu.
sp.l: It ſhall be a warning to me: in th'meane time
Would it were raz'd out of the Kalender quite,

It is a day prodigious.
Enter Changeable and Slightall.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: If I can prove that all thy debts be paid
Thou art my owne, was't not, and ſpeake thy conſcience,
Our joynt condition?

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: That Uſurer's one of thy maine Creditors,
But when thou waſt ſo free to pay thy debts, thou ne're
Dream'ſt of thy forfeit; propoſe to him thy queſtion.

sp.speaker: Sl
sp.l: And I will, I bid thee that thy money
Ne're ſhall doe, ſave thee.

sp.speaker: Vſu.
sp.l: Beſhrow you ſir, you made me ſtart,
What is your will with me?

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: I ſpeake to thee
As to the Drawer at the Vintners Barre:
What is all paid?

sp.speaker: Vſu.
sp.l: And like the Bar-boy I
When you bring ready mony, and keepe touch
All's pay'd ſir, and y'are welcome.

sp.speaker: Scri.
sp.p: What's he that lookes ſo gaſtly?

sp.speaker: Scri.
sp.p: My Pen and Inkhorne bleſſe me.

sp.speaker: Vſu.
sp.l: All thoſe croſſes that I have figur'd on the
Princes Coyne, ſtand ſtill betwixt me and danger,

div.stage: Exeunt Vſu. and Scri.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: Theſe are diſcharg'd, what refuge haſt thou now?
Nay bring me unto all thy Creditors;
Ile prove thy debts diſcharg'd.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: I pray how many
Of our beſt London Gallants that hope Heaven,
Can ſay the like? merit I Hell for that?

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.p: But I muſt have my bargaine.

div.stage: Enter two Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.p: Haſt thou not ow'd to theſe?

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: Reſolve me friends, as you are Gentlemen,
In what knowne ſummes did this man ſtand ingag'd to
Each of you?

sp.speaker: Gen. 1.
sp.l: I know not why you aske ſir,
But the time was he ought me ſome few peeces,
I thought them deſperate once, but nobly, ſince
He to the full hath ſeene me ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Gen. 2.
sp.l: I never met with a more generous debtor,
I onely truſted him with ſome few ſummes,
And he hath paid me uſe and principall,
A thing I ne're expected.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: That's all Gentlemen—morow

sp.speaker: Gen. 1.
sp.l: The like to you; I wonder what the Divell
Slightall ayles, he lookes ſo ſtrangely on us?

sp.speaker: Gen. 2.
sp.p: Sparkes no doubt, of his firſt madneſſe. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.p: Doe but name the man, to whom thou canſt appeale.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: I muſt confeſſe I'me gone by th'common Law,
The Chancery too, becauſe of thee, my conſcience,
If to any, I appeale to the Church.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p:
To any reverent Father.
Ent. Frier. Ber. and Frier Iohn.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.p: Then to theſe, to both, or either, freely take thy choice.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Holy Frier Bernard then, my parting breath
Could not deſire a better confeſſor.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.p: Reade there, and tell me what thou think'ſt of that.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Give me but leave to take my ſecond eyes,
I will reſolve you preſently.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.p: In th'interim, what's the beſt newes in the pariſh?

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Ile tell thee all I know,
We are better to the Suburbes than they planted
Within the City; thereon holy dayes
The taverne doores are ever ſhut till ſixe,
Elſe is the Vintner fin'd; but there where wee
Keepe rendevous may be let in at three, and never ſtir
The Informers.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Ten thouſand Creeds, as many Pater-noſters,
Ave Maries ſtand betweene me and harme.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: In theſe conditions, I like a cunning Lawyer find a
Clauſe to cheate the Divell, and to ſave a ſoule;
Be'ſt thou the greateſt fell with Lucifer,
Nay he himſelfe, I now am arm'd for thee: what claim'ſt
Thou of this man?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: By helpe of Heaven I ſhall: this deede thus runs;
When all his Creditors are ſatisfied,
His Bonds diſcharg'd and cancell'd, debts full paid,
His Morgages call'd in, his words redeem'd,
This Bond is then in vertue; not till then.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: All this I grant, and call to witneſſe none
Save his owne Conſcience; art thou not at freedome,
And cleare from all the world?

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Moſt true, I am,
Nor can I name that party under Heaven
To whom I owe one farthing; a braſſe token
Will cancell all my ſcores.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: What were the ſummes for which he ſtood ingag'd?

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: Some fifteene thouſand pounds, which I have pay'd,
And now the man owes nothing; therefore duely I
Claime both ſoule and body.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Both are quit,
As thou thy ſelfe ſhalt to thy griefe confeſſe;
For I will prove him more indebted now
Than e're he was before.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: To thee,
Whom till he have diſcharg'd the utmoſt penny,
The Bond's of no effect.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: The Divell hath bragg'd he hath caught many a Frier,
Now one hath caught the Divell.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Yes, till thou pay'ſt him all his money downe,
Which when thou doeſt th'art worthy to be damn'd.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Inſert but that condition'mongſt the reſt,
And I'le againe ſubſcribe; Gramercy Frier.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: Nay then I ſee vainely we Divells ſtand againſt the
Church, they have ſtill the upper hand,
I yeeld me vanquiſh'd; in the meame time Frier read
And conceale. Gives him another paper to reade.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: What, by a quid d it freed? by a quirke in the Law? by
This I ſee the Divell's no good Lawyer: give me my deed,
That I may ſee it cancell'd and undone:
Ile teare it ſmall as Atomes, that no memory
Of the leaſt Letter be reſerv'd as witneſſe
Againſt my ſoule when I ſhall reſurvive;
Nor ſhall I be at patience till I ſee
This Parchment aſhes, and this horrid Writ
Diſſolv'd to ſmoake and aire.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: Yet for my love,
For all the good thou haſt receiv'd by me,
For all my coſt and charges, large expence,
As I acquit thee truely, ſo thou freely
Lend me thine eare.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Thy bounty hath deſerv'd it▪
To ſave a ſoule I know no Scrivener here
That would not onely lend but give an eare.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I am inform'd to th'full; if this be true,
Divell, th' art honeſt, and ſhalt have thy due:
Aſſociate me Frier Iohn.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: With all my heart,
If this be Asteroth I ſo late invoakt, I never ſhall deſire
His company, but on an empty ſtomacke. Ex. Friers.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: And ſhall I meet her there?

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: And enjoy her to:
Doe thou but hazard as thou did'ſt before
And doubt not, ſhe's thine owne.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.p: As a contracted Bride and Bed-fellow.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: No difference in her ſhape and ornament?

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Thou canſt doe much with me, nor doe I
Know beyond what bounds thy credence to extend: thou
May'ſt prove falſe, but th'haſt bin yet my friend. Exeunt all.

div.head: Act. 5. Scaen. 3.
div.stage: Enter Anne in Bed, Miſtris Changeable, Lord Skales, Treatwell and Geffery.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Let him ſtay,
Deaths Image cannot ſhew ſo gaſtly to me
As would the ſhape of Doctor, Ile have none.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: If he come
Good faith Ile live no longer.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Sooth her up,
Or ſhe will grow to frenzy.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Sicke, oh ſicke at heart, and you keepe ſuch a buzzing
In my eares, that I can take no reſt;
Would you would leave mee.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: From whom, if't
Be his will, the Lord deliver me.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Your abſence,
Mother, and yours, and all of you; I am but dead
Unleſſe you give me reſt; oh ſicke, ſicke, ſicke,
Your tongues like untun'd Bells, ſound in my eares,
Nothing but Grave and Church-yard.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Whom wilt have
To watch with thee all night?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: None but my Father,
All tongues are noiſe and diſcords ſaving his;
But his like charming Muſicke, quietly
Summons my eyes to reſt; and could I ſleepe once
I hope I ſhould be better, oh.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I ſhall diſclaime all friendſhip with that tongue
That ſpeakes another ſillable; this prating
It ſtrikes quite through my head, and makes it beate
As it would fall in peeces.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Mother, you talke of ſilence, and yet ſpeake; how can that be?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: if you were ſicke at heart as I, you'de
Say mum were a word, Mum ſounds to me, being ſicke,
Loud as a Cannon; why ſo? I thanke you all, indeed you
Doe me now a wondrous kindneſſe; I pray, pray for me, I
ſhall be well at midnight, well at heart;
And at head too I hope: and Mother, nay reply not,
I'me like the man that could endure no noiſe
In'th ſilent woman, anſwer all in ſignes;
Mother I hope ere morning I ſhall find
Some more hearts eaſe; remember when you ſee't,
I told you of't before hand: I would ſleepe:
Hand in my bed, Ile turne to the wall, and try if I can
Sleepe, ſo good night all. The Bed pull'd in

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: So, ſoftly as you can; ſome little reſt
Will bring her to her temper, for this night
We will commit her to her Fathers charge, ſince ſhe ſo
Much deſires it.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Any thing to give her leaſt content.

div.stage: Enter old Changeable and Roger.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: Thou knowſt my mind, what thou haſt undertooke
Mannage with good diſcretion.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: 'Tis as ſafe
Here in my breaſt as under bolts and lockes,
The cunning'ſt pick-locke tongue that ever ſpake
Shall turne theſe ſprings to ope them; farewell ſir.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: Farewell good Roger, but no word to' your Maſter
Of what I have reveal'd thee kept from him.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: As I would doe a kindneſſe, lay't in me,
From my old fellow Geffery. Exit.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: Now my Lord; I am ſtill labouring for the generall
Good, to have my houſe at peace, and you content;
But Wife, how is't with Nan?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Sir, wondrous ill,
She will endure no counſell, phyſicke, language,
All tongues are clamour to her, ſaving yours,
Harſh as a blacke Sant, or a grating Wheele;
And I much feare without ſome providence, ſhe ſcarce
Will live till morning.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: But ſhe entreats in midd'ſt of all extreames
That you would take the paines to watch with her,
No other ſhe'le endure.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: And ſir, I'le doe't,
No other tongue this night ſhall trouble her, nor preſence
Save my owne; ſhall I entreate your Lordſhip, you good
Wife, and thoſe you thinke beſt to aſſociate you,
To ſtand in ſight of all ſuch Apparitions
As ſhall in this roome be made viſible?
My life ſhall for your ſafety be • ngag'd, in it can be no
Danger.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: What aſſurance can you produce for that?

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: The word and faith of ſome approv'd religious,
Who have promiſ'd, at my great interceſſion, that this
Night ſhall be the laſt of all my progidies
That thus afflict my houſe.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: I am but one and I my ſelfe will venture.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.l: Faith
And I.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: I do not think wife but there will be viſions
Worthy both ſight and obſervation to;
What will you ſay if Slightall be this night
Contract to a ſhe fury? but no words,
Ile not tell you all I know; he's paſt his ſence
And apt for any ſtratagem of Hell: I am promiſ'd
Much faire hope; will you aſcend and guide my Lord to a
Convenient place, where you may view this object?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: In th'meane time, how will you diſpoſe your ſelfe?

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: To watch with Nan,
And in her great diſpaire to comfort her;
Nought but the dangerous ſickneſſe of my Girle
Could keepe me from you, but the houre drawes on,
Which Ghoſts ever are tyed to.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Mauger ſpirits, Ile
Once take ſpirit into me.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: A woman lead? They aſcend.
'Twere baſeneſſe not to follow.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: My Girle's my
Charge, ſhe hath bin ever ſo, and therefore ought
This night; and ſince one Divell ſome
Few dayes ſince began to haunt my houſe
She ne're had peace of thought, health, nor content,
Or leaſt eſſentiall comfort; which to compaſſe,
All Art, wit, learning, this night Ile implore
To drive him hence, ſhall haunt my houſe no more. Exit.

Thunder.
Enter above Lord, Wife, Treatwell, and Geffery.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: The Larum's given;
For at that watch word ſtill the rufling noyſe begins.

div.stage: Enter Fryers, Bernard and Iohn at ſeverall doores, as hallowing the Roome.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.p: My lord theſe Friers I know.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: But whether
They, or but their ſhadowes by Art Magicke raiſ'd we
Cannot yet preſume.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: But this I'me ſure.
They are exceeding like.

div.stage: Frier Bernard fetches in at his doore Slightall, and Roger, Frier Io. at his, Anne and the Divell.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: That can be none but Slightall.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.l: My Lord ſee, my
Fellow Roger's damn'd, for he's got in
Among the Fiends and Furies.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Were I not certaine my daughter Nan were deſperately
Sicke, and kept both Bed and Chamber, I durſt ſweare
That were my Girle.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.l: Is ſhe not dead to night, and
Now her Ghoſt there walkes?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: What might we
Thinke of't? the Friers prepare for Marriage; but what, he
Stands for the Father, whom they beckon to, to give
Her hand to Slightall.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.l: Now I have't;
Upon my life the Divell can be no better; ſhe the illuſive
Spirit by whom this roome was haunted, contracted
Now unto yon deſperate Ruffian.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: But this troubles me, the Fury ſhould aſſume no other
Shape but her faire Angell beauty.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: Even for that, great reaſon too, would I could underſtand it.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Becauſe he was enamoured firſt on her,
The more to tempt him, ſhe aſſum'd that ſhape,
Whom elſe could ſhe ſo fitly perſonate?
Nay goe together, you have my conſent,
Ile ne're forbid the Banes.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Much joy unto you, good troth nor I.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: The Divell give you good of't.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: And ſo the
Divell doth, for your kind conſent my Lord I thanke you,
And gentle wife for yours.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: And, next my Father,
I hold it my fit duty, thankes to both.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Let me leape downe the next way, for the contract
I vow to breake.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: But Miſtris, that's the next way
To breake your necke, and keepe the contract firme;
The Staire-caſe will doe better.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Fool'd and deluded? give me way my Lord,
For I will downe among them.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Hye to ſhelter, for there's a ſtorme comming.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: That you are man, this woman, I am rapt
And extaſy'd in braine, but cannot yet
Unwrappe my ſences from this wondrous maze;
This ſuddaine light of knowledge ſo much dazels,
That in my judgement I am blinded quite,
And know not how to free me.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: That anon, my Daughter making knowne your
Deepe diſpaire, your helpe I ſtudied both of purſe and braine,
And fearing a loſt ſoule, I then turn'd Divell,
To prove your better Angell; talke with her,
For I muſt arme for thunder.

div.stage: Enter Lord, Wife, Treatwell, and Geffery.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: Was this a marriage in the Divells name?

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: Yes, and his Dam in preſence; ſhe lookt on.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: Were you ſicke with a vengeance?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: But I told you I ſhould be well by Midnight;
So good Mother I feele my ſelfe I am well, never better

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Shall I be plaine, my Lord? I crave your pardon,
Wife, for your rage I am arm'd, yes,
If thou could'ſt encounter with
Fleſh-hookes, and with Fire-brands; for I tell thee
I am practiſ'd in the Divell: but to you, my Lord,
I paſſ'd my faith unto this Gentleman,
Had it beene done to you I ne're had broke it.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Sir you ſpeake nobly;
What muſt bee, muſt be: it is in the will of Heaven,
And I am well pleaſ'd with it.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: And am I over-reach'd? well Slightall,
My bleſſing on thee, ſhe's thine.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Mother, my Knee in duty bowes thus low:
My Lord, your hand, I hope no
Malice harbours in your heart.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: Sir I doe not; and all I hope are pleaſ'd.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: If theſe be ſo, we then are happy,
We are new wedded, you are our chiefe Gueſt,
Though once my Rivall, now you are my friend:
My fortune thus all malice hath defeated,
And by a new trike the Grand Divell cheated.

div.stage: Exeunt Omnes.
